sp.p: She is dressing . We are going to the ball at the Gontiers ’ to-night , and the dear child asked if she might dress before dinner .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Not that she is vain .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Not the least in the world . DUPONTto his wife , in an off-hand toneShe makes her own dresses , does n't she ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Of course . In this house we do n't know what it is to have a bill from the dressmaker .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Yet with all her other occupations she 's an excellent musician .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Quite excellent . She has a passion for really good music . She knows Wagner thoroughly .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Wagner ! Good heavens !

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: To talk about , I mean .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: I know your daughter is charming .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: And good , too . You would never believe how responsive that poor child is to affection ! DUPONTto Mairaut , offering the boxHave a cigar ?

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: No , thanks . I never smoke before dinner .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Take one , all the same . You can smoke it afterwards . They are my usual brand , but pretty fair . MAIRAUTtaking oneThank you .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: If Antonin is not married already it is because his father and I wished him to find a wife who is worthy of him . The question of money , with us , is of secondary importance .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: And with us . I 'm so glad we agree about that .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Antonin might have made quite a number of good matches .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: It is just the same with Julie . In spite of that unfortunate affair in the family .

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: Yes , we know .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Unfortunate affair ? We have heard nothing of any unfortunate affair . What are you saying , my dear ? MAIRAUTmumbling confusedlyI was saying — nothing — I was saying — No , I was n't saying anything .

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: MAIRAUTto Madame DupontThen there has been some unfortunate affair in your family ?

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Yes . By my first marriage I had two daughters . One , that great fool of a Caroline whom you know .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Quite well . She remains unmarried , does she not ?

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: She prefers it . That 's the only reason . The other was called Angele . When she was seventeen she was guilty of an indiscretion which it became impossible to hide . I turned her out of my house .Quite sincerelyI was deeply distressed at having to do it .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: For three days he refused to eat anything .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Yes , I was terribly distressed . But I knew my duty as a man of honor , and I did it .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: It was noble of you !She shakes him warmly by the hand

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: Since you were so fond of her , perhaps it would have been better to keep her with you .

lg.l: My dear , you are speaking without thinking .
And what has become of her ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: In India ? DUPONTto Madame DupontYes , with her aunt , a sister of my first wife 's . I have had news of her from time to time .To Madame MairautIndirectly , of course .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: I repeat , M. Dupont , all this does you honor .ThoughtfullyStill , some people might feel — However , I do n't think this discovery need make us abandon our project at once . Not at once .To MairautWhat do you think , my dear ? MAIRAUT . I ?

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: You think , as I do , that we must take time to consider , do you not ?A pauseWithout any definite promise on either side , but merely in order to get rid of all money questions , which are most distasteful to me , will you allow me to ask you one question , M. Dupont ?

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Certainly , Madame Mairaut .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Have you ever consideredshe hesitateswhat you would give your daughter ?

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Oh , yes — roughly , you know .

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: Just so .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: And the sum is — roughly ?

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Fifty thousand francs .

lg.l: M. Dupont will give his daughter only fifty thousand francs .

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: Yes .A pause

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: In cash , of course .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Twentyfive thousand at once . Twentyfive thousand in six months .

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: MAIRAUTto MairautYou hear ?

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: For practical purposes that is only twentyfive thousand francs and a promise . DUPONTwith dignityTwentyfive thousand francs and my word .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Precisely . That is what I saidlooking at her husbandUnder these circumstances , we regret very much , but M. Mairaut must decline . It really is not enough .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: How much are you giving M. Antonin ?

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Not a sou ! On that point we are quite decided and quite frank . As soon as he marries his father will take him into partnership , and his wife 's dot will be the capital which he will put into the business .

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: That is the exact position .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Antonin will have nothing except what may come to him after our death .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: And I am glad to think you are both in excellent health .

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: MAIRAUTmodestlyThat is so .

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: DUPONTmeditativelyHas n't your son an uncle , by the way ?

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Yes , madame .

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: Uncle Marechal .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: People say M. Marechal has a great affection for M. Antonin .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: Very great .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: He is rich , too , people say .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: So they say .

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: However , we have n't taken him into account , have we ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Still , M. Marechal would naturally leave everything to his nephew .

div.stage: MAIRAUT & MME . MAIRAUT [ together ] Oh , certainly . We can promise that . He will leave him everything he has .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT . M
sp.p: Marechal has considerable influence at the Prefecture , has he not ?

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: No doubt . But all this is really beside the mark . At twentyfive thousand francs we could not —

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: I am sorry .

lg.stage: She rises , saying to her husband
lg.l: Come , my dear , we must be taking our leave .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: I might , perhaps , go to thirty thousand .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: I am afraid fifty thousand is the lowest .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Let us split the difference . Thirty thousand and my country house at St. Laurent .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: But it is flooded two months out of the twelve .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Flooded ! Never .

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: MAIRAUTto her husbandWell , my dear , what do you think ?

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: Antonin is much attached to Mlle . Julie .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Ah , yes , if it were not for that !Seats herselfMy poor boy !She weeps

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: My poor little Julie !She weepsMAIRAUTto DupontYou must excuse her . After all , it is her son .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: My dear sir , I quite understand .

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: MAIRAUTwiping her eyesAnd , of course , there would be the other twentyfive thousand in six months .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Of course .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Have you any views as to settlements ?

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: On that point I have very definite ideas .

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: So have I .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: The money on each side must be strictly settled .

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: Strictly settled ?A silence of astonishment

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: His and hers ?

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Certainly . You agree ?

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: Oh , yes , I agree , I agree . Unless you preferred —

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: That all moneys should be held jointly ?

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: Perhaps that would be —

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Perhaps so . There is something distasteful , I might almost say sordid , about strict settlements .

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: That 's it . Something sordid .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: They imply a certain distrust .

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: Yes , do n't they ? Well , that 's agreed , then ?

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Quite . The moneys to be held jointly . All moneys , that is , that may come to them in the future . The first twentyfive thousand , of course , will be settled on Julie . They will form the dot .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: The second twentyfive thousand , which you will pay over in six months , to be held jointly .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Yes . We will draw up a little agreement .

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: Quite so . Antonin Mairaut comes in . He is a handsome youth of twenty-eight , very correct in manner . Greetings are exchanged .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Antonin .To Dupont and Madame DupontYou allow me ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: By all means .

lg.stage: She draws Antonin aside and says to him in a low voice

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: How much ?

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Thirty thousand , the house , and twentyfive thousand in six months .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Good .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Now you 've only the girl to deal with .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Is she romantic or matter of fact ? I do n't quite know .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Romantic . Raves about Wagner .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Good heavens !

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: So I said . But once she 's married and has children to look after —

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Children ! Do n't go too fast . Children come pretty expensive nowadays . Troublesome , too .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Never mind . Do n't cross her now . Later on , of course , you 'll be master .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: I rather think so .

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: MAIRAUTreturning to Madame DupontMy dear madame —

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Yes ?

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: He is afraid he may not please Mlle . Julie .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Absurd !

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: The amount of the dot , too —

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: It is my last word .To his wifeBut what is Julie about ?He rings

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: DUPONTrisesI will go and find her . A maid enters .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Wait !To the maidAsk Mlle . Julie to come here if she is ready . The maid goes out .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: I must tell you , monsieur and madame , how flattered I am to find that the preliminaries have been settled between you and my parents on this important question . I do not know what will be the issue , but —

lg.l: It is we , monsieur , who are flattered . But you 'll see
Julie in a moment . Of course she knows nothing .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: We might leave them to talk a little together , perhaps ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: By all means . We are going to the ball at the Gontiers ’ . She asked to be allowed — Here she is .Julie comes in . Madame Mairaut advances to meet herThere is a crease in your dress , dear .She takes her apart , saying to the MairautsWill you excuse me ? JULIEin a low toneWell ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: It rests entirely with you . We are going to leave you to talk together . Remember , it may be your last chance . Do n't throw it away .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: I have thought it over and I do n't intend to do as Caroline did . So if , after we have had a talk —

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: You 'll have to manage him a little . He has a great eye for business . If you could make him think you would be useful in the bank .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: But I hate figures .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Once married you will do as you please . Tuck in that lace a bit . It 's a little soiled .She tucks in the lace of Julie 's corsageAnd remember , between lovers there may be little things which he considers himself entitled to .

lg.l: I understand . They can see you whispering . Go to them .
lg.stage: Madame Dupont goes back to Madame Mairaut

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: What did she say ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: She has not the least suspicion at present .

lg.l: I have long wished to go over a printing office . May we ?
If you will kindly come this way .

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: Thank you .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: But there really are too many of us .CarelesslyThe children might stay here , do n't you think , madame ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: By all means . They go out . ANTONINlooking at the music on the pianoYou are fond of Wagner , mademoiselle .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: I adore him .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: So do I .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: What a genius he is .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Wonderful .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: For me he is the only composer .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: The greatest , certainly .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: No : the only one .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Perhaps so . How nice it is we should have the same tastes in art !PauseEr — they have told you nothing , I understand ?

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: About what ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Your parents , I mean . Mine have said nothing either .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: They have said nothing , of course , but I guessed .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: So did I . Then I may consider myself engaged to you ?

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Oh , not yet . We must know each other better first .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: We have often danced together .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Yes . But that 's hardly enough .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: It 's enough for me . Ever since the first time I saw you at the ball at the Prefecture .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: No . It was at the band , one Sunday , that your mother first introduced you to me .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Was it ? I forgot .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: I should like to know more about you . Will you — will you let me ask you some questions ? It is not usual , perhaps , but —

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Certainly . Pray ask them .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Are you fond of children ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Passionately .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Really and truly ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Really and truly .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: I am quite crazy about them . For me children mean happiness . They are the one thing worth living forwistfullyBut I think I have a higher idea of marriage than most girls . I want to have my mind satisfied as well as my heart .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: So do I .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: A marriage that is a mere business partnership seems to me horrible .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Horrible ! That 's just the word .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: And tell me , are you very fond of society ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Not particularly . Are you ?

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: I am delighted to hear it . The fact is I am sick to death of parties and balls . Still , if it were necessary for business reasons : if it would help to get business for the bank , you would n't mind ?

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Of course not . What kind of business do you do at your bank ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Oh , the usual kind .

lg.l: I have often read what is put up on the wall , Current Accounts ,

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Coupons cashed .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: That must be very interesting .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Would you take an interest in all that ?

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Of course . When I was little my father used to make me help him with his books .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: But now ?

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Now , unfortunately , he has a clerk . I am sorry .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Do you know that you are charming ?

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: So you told me once before .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Yes : at that ball . You had on a dress just like this one . You are beautiful . Beautiful .He seizes her handJULIEa little troubledPlease .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Come . We are engaged , as good as married . Give me one kiss .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: No . No .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Wo n't you ? JULIEfrightenedNo , I tell you .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: What beautiful arms you have .He draws her towards himYou remember how I adored you when we were dancing .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Let me go . ANTONINgreatly excited , in a low voiceDo n't move . You are entrancing .He kisses her upon the arm ; she pulls it away sharply

lg.stage: after looking at him for some time

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Well , when I see that you positively dislike me .Julie , after a short inward struggle , goes to himJULIEputting her arm to his lips with a resigned sadness , which she hides from himAntonin . ANTONINkissing her armOh , I love you . I love you .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Hush . They are coming back . The Mairauts and Duponts come in again .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: And when I have the contract from the Prefecture I shall double my business .

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: Excellent . Excellent .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: We must be going , dear madame . We have stayed far too long already . Are you coming , Antonin ? ANTONINto Julie , aloud , bowing profoundlyMademoiselle .In a low voiceMy beloved Julie .To his motherShe 's charming . I was charming , too , by the way . Wagner , children , every kind of romantic idiocy . And she believed me .Aloud to DupontM. and Madame Dupont , my parents will have the honor of calling upon you to-morrow to ask on my behalf for the hand of Mlle . Julie .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Till to-morrow , then . Till to-morrow .To AntoninAll sorts of messages to your uncle , if you see him .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: I shall not fail .He bows . The Mairauts take their leaveDUPONTto JulieThat 's all right , then ?

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Yes . I really do like him . I think I managed him pretty well too . Wagner . The bank . He thinks I 've a perfect passion for banking . DUPONTlaughingGood . You 're my own daughter . Kiss me . And your father ? He managed pretty well , I think . I have arranged that all moneys except your dot shall be held by you both jointly ; so that if you are divorced , or if you die after Uncle Marechal , your dot will come back to us , and half whatever he leaves . I call that a good day 's work . And at dessert we 'll drink a bottle of the best to the health of Madame Antonin Mairaut .

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: DUPONTembracing herMy poor little daughter .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Poor , indeed ! She 's a very lucky girl . I wonder where that great stupid Caroline has got to .He callsCaroline . She is never here when one wants her .He calls againCaroline . She is hard at work painting Cupids on plates , I bet .Caroline appearsHere she is . Great news . Your sister is engaged to be married .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: Julie . Is it true ?

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: Ah !

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Is that all you have to say ?

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: I am very glad , very glad .She bursts into tearsDUPONTastonishedWhat 's wrong with her ? Crying ! And she 's not even asked who he is . She 's to marry M. Antonin Mairaut , nephew of M. Marechal .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Do n't cry like that , my dear .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Caroline . CAROLINEtrying to restrain her sobsDo n't mind me . It is only because I love you , dear . Now you at least will be happy . JULIEmusingYes . DUPONTto himselfThe moral of all this is that that little affair of Angele 's is costing me an extra five thousand francs and my house at St. Laurent .

stage.stage: The salon of a house in the country . A July night . At the back through glass doors you see the garden brilliantly lighted by the moon . As you look out you have two doors on your right-hand side , and to your left , in a cross-wall , the door of the bedroom , inside which part of the bed is visible . The fireplace is to your right . When the curtain rises Antonin , Courthezon and Caroline are on the stage ; Caroline is doing up a parcel .

lg.l: That 's settled , then , M. Courthezon . I 'll write to the
Bordeaux people about your invention this evening .

sp.speaker: COURTHEZON
sp.p: I am greatly obliged to you , M. Antonin . You 'll write this evening without fail , wo n't you ? M. Smith is leaving tomorrow .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Without fail .

sp.speaker: COURTHEZON
sp.p: Shall I post the letter for you on my way through the town ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Well — it 's rather a difficult letter to write . It 'll take a little time . Lignol , whom you met at dinner out in the garden , has to go back tonight . He 'll take it .

sp.speaker: COURTHEZON
sp.p: It 's very good of you .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: And now let 's go and have our coffee .

sp.speaker: COURTHEZON
sp.p: Not for me , thanks . I 'm afraid I ought to go by the 8. 9 train . I shall be taking some china for Mdlle . Caroline and the drawings .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: As you please . Good-bye , then .

sp.speaker: COURTHEZON
sp.p: Good-bye , M. Antonin . Thank you again .Antonin goes out

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: I shall not keep you a moment . The parcel is just ready .

sp.speaker: COURTHEZON
sp.p: There is no hurry , mademoiselle . I can take the next train . It 's of no importance . Indeed I prefer it . It carries third-class passengers . The fact is I did n't want to go back to the others . M. and Madame . Mairaut , M. Lignol , all those people frighten me . Besides , I 'm so happy just now I can think of nothing else .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE . M
sp.p: Antonin is going to do something about your invention ?

sp.speaker: COURTHEZON
sp.p: Yes . I have begun negotiations with a business house at Bordeaux . M. Antonin knows the heads of the firm , and he has been kind enough to say he will write to them about me . But M. Smith goes away to-morrow . That was why I was so anxious the letter should go tonight . CAROLINEgiving him the parcel which she has just finishedIt 's very kind of you to take charge of this . I have put the china in it and the drawings they asked for . You will make my apologies to the firm , wo n't you ? I have not been very well .

sp.speaker: COURTHEZON
sp.p: Not well ?

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: Nothing serious . But the doctor said a little country air would be good for me , so Julie and her husband asked me here . They have been very kind . I have been with them a week , and I 'm feeling ever so much better .

sp.speaker: COURTHEZON
sp.p: They would hardly have left you in your lodgings with no one to look after you .PauseWhat a strange idea it was of yours to go off and live by yourself like that !

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: I thought it better . After Julie 's marriage I preferred it .

sp.speaker: COURTHEZON
sp.p: It must cost more . CAROLINEshrugsI daresay .PauseYou are going to have a lovely night for your journey . How bright the moon is ! One can see as clearly as if it were broad daylight . COURTHEZONsuddenly rememberingThere now ! I was just going to forget ! I brought a letter for M. Dupont from the office . It came after he left . It 's about the printing contract for the Prefecture .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: For the Prefecture . He 'll want to see that directly he comes in .

sp.speaker: COURTHEZON
sp.p: And now I really must be off . Good-bye , Mlle . Caro .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: Good-bye , M. Courthezon .He goes outAfter Courthezon 's departure Caroline returns to her seat . She makes a slight sign of the cross , closes her eyes and sits motionless , praying silently . After a few seconds she again crosses herself , but does all this very quietly . Lignol comes in through the glass doors , giving his arm to Julie . Antonin and M. and Madame Mairaut follow .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: We shall be more comfortable here than in the garden . It 's getting rather chilly .To LignolYou can smoke .

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: We really could have stayed out quite well .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: And given Julie cold , eh ?

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: My dear , I assure you —

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Oh , yes , I know . But you are n't wrapped up enough .He touches her armIn that thin dress you 've simply nothing on . Just feel , Lignol , feel . JULIEprotestingMy dear !

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: What a charming frock you have on , my dear . Quite delightful .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: It came from Madame Raimond .

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: MAIRAUTto MairautFrom Madame Raimond ? I thought she made all her own dresses . LIGNOLto JulieYou know , madame , that you have not convinced me yet .

lg.stage: They go towards the garden door with Antonin , talking

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: MAIRAUTto MairautAnd you urged on that marriage . MAIRAUT . I !

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: When she was at home she never went to a dressmaker . And now ! It 's too much . And we shall have the river in here before long . That wall is bound to go .

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: Do you think so ?

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: We shall have the whole house about our ears . And that fool —

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: What fool ?

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Your son , of course , who has put in electric light . ANTONINfrom the garden door , to LignolYou did n't know I 'd had electric light put in . We have lots of water power , you see . I ought to have turned it on before . Look .He touches a button and turns up the light

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: That 's better .They talk on

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: If the river rises another couple of inches down will come four hundred feet of that wall .

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: It 's not as bad as that .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Oh , you have let yourself be nicely done .

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: Come , come .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: The girl is utterly useless . She can do nothing . And the house will cost more in repairs than it is worth . When I think I was idiot enough to listen to you .She listensWhat was that ?

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: I hear nothing .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: The wall ! Listen !They listen intentlyJULIEcoming forward with Lignol and AntoninOh , yes , we 're comfortable enough here , as you see .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Comfortable enough !To MairautCome with me . This way . I am certain the wall has fallen . If it has we must have a little talk with the Duponts ; and I , for one , sha n't mince matters .Turning to the othersMy husband finds the heat a little too much for him . We are going for another turn in the garden . Oh , it 's nothing , nothing at all . MAIRAUTmumblingNothing . Giddy , that 's all .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Quite right . Get all the fresh air you can while you are in the country . Do n't be long . We 're expecting visitors , you know .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: We 'll be back in time .Madame Mairaut and Mairaut go out into the garden

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Here , you see , is the staircase which leads to the upstairs rooms and down to the garden .He goes to the door on his leftHere is our bedroom . JULIEin a low voice , so as not to be noticed by LignolAntonin ! ANTONINaloudNonsense , dear . Why not ?He opens the door . To LignolLook .

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: Charming .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: A real nest , eh ? A nest for love-birds . That 's what I call it .To his wifeKiss me , dear .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: But —

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Kiss me . Come . JULIEgentlyBut we 're not alone .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Lignol wo n't mind . Eh , Lignol ? LIGNOLlaughsDo n't mention it . You were n't so shy at dinner . ANTONINto Julie , smilingCome . Wives must obey , you know .She kisses himAnd now go and see about that beer .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: May n't I send the servant ?

lg.l: She does n't know where it is . It 's not unpacked yet .
It 's a wedding present . We are going to broach it tonight .

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: Not for me . I must go in a moment .

lg.l: I was n't thinking of you , my dear fellow . You 're a friend .
These formal entertainments are reserved for acquaintances . For the
Pouchelets , in fact . M. Pouchelet has just been elected a Departmental
Councillor . He and his wife are paying their first visit here tonight .

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: So late ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: On their way back from the Prefet 's . They are dining there , and we are near neighbors . They are very well off , very influential . Useful people altogether . What was I saying ?To JulieOh yes , the beer : that girl will never be able to find it . Besides , I 'd rather you went . She would only break the bottles .Julie poutsWives must obey , you know .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Very well . I shall be back before you go , M. Lignol .She goes outCAROLINEto AntoninYou wo n't forget the letter for M. Courthezon , will you , M. Antonin .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Of course not .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: If you write I feel sure he will succeed .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Yes , yes , I know .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: I will go to Julie .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: You 'd much better go and put on another dress or something . Just to smarten yourself up . The Pouchelets are coming . We must all look our best . CAROLINErather aghast , looking at her clothesBut —A pauseVery well .She goes out

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: Who is that lady ? She never spoke a word all through dinner . ANTONINcarelesslyA poor relation . The usual thing , an old maid , always at church . Awfully prim and proper , you know .Rather shamefacedIn fact — I do n't mind telling you — she really works for her living .

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: Well , why not ? There 's nothing dishonorable about that , is there ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: I know . But still — She paints little Cupids and that kind of thing , on china .He laughs loudlyEnough to make you split ! You do n't see it ? The other day someone offered her some work far better paid than what she 's doing at present . She refused . Guess why . LIGNOLboredWhy ? ANTONINgigglingBecause the woman who kept the shop was divorced .He laughsBut it is good to see you again , my dear chap .He claps Lignol on the shoulderAwfully good .

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: I 've enjoyed coming immensely .A pauseYour wife is charming . ANTONINfatuouslyNot bad , eh !

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: And she 's clever , too .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Get out !

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: I 'm quite serious .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Oh , yes , I dare say . I know all about that . No use denying it . Julie 's stupid . It was partly for that very reason I married her .

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: I do n't think so . She has read a lot .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Read ! Oh , yes , she 's read ! She reads everything she comes across . Before her marriage she read the proofs of everything her father printed . Here she has unearthed a lot of books left behind by an old fool M. Dupont bought the house from . She 's read them all .

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: But then —

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: But she does n't understand a word of what she reads . Not a word ! The other day I looked at the author 's name on the book in her hand . It was Mill . You know , John Stuart Mill . LIGNOLnodsYes , I know .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: So do I , by name . But I 've never read him , thank goodness . No , I tell you Julie 's stupid . But she 's pretty and she knows how to put on her clothes . I knew what I was about when I married her . With a little instruction from me she 'll learn to manage the house well enough . And that 's all I ask of a woman .

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: Indeed . Well , my dear chap , if you imagine you 've married a stupid woman you 're mistaken .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: How do you know ?

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: She and I have been talking while you were entertaining your inventor .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: You got her to talk , did you ?

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: Certainly .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Wonders will never cease . When we 're alone she never has a word to say .

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: And you ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: I have n't either .

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: That 's awkward .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: I 'm always afraid of putting my foot in it . The fact is I do n't understand Julie .

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: And you 've been married five months .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Four months and a week over . But then I 'm at business all the week . Every Saturday her parents and mine come down to spend Sunday with us . M. and Madame Dupont could n't get here in time for dinner tonight , but they 'll be here soon . When we are alone I try to find some subject of conversation , but I tell you it 's like walking on eggshells . Whew ! And so —

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: And so I stop . And then I kiss her .

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: You 're tremendously in love with her .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: And she ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: She 's just the same .

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: Happy man !

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: For the rest we can only wait and see how things turn out . She knows nothing of my tastes . I know nothing of hers .

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: And what did you talk about while you were engaged ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: We were only engaged three weeks . Just long enough to get the money matters settled .

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: You took good care about them , I bet .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Rather . In fact it was a precious good stroke of business .He laughsIf you only knew how we did the Duponts , maman and I !He laughs again

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: Hush . Here 's your wife .Julie comes in , and Lignol rises to goI am afraid I must be going , madame .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: But my letter for Courthezon .He looks at his watchYou 've twenty minutes still .

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: You 're sure ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Certain . Wait a second . I 'll go and write it , and then I 'll see you to the station . It 's only a step .He goes out

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Thanks to you , M. Lignol , we have had a delightful evening .

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: You flatter me , dear madame . I know quite well I have been in the way .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: On the contrary . I have not had such an evening 's conversation since I married .

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: Antonin is n't a great talker .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: You are old friends , are n't you ?

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: Yes . I 've known him fifteen years . We are almost like brothers .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Tell me . Is he what you would call a religious man ?

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: Antonin !Bursts out laughingWhy , he 's a materialist . Not much idealism about him .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Indeed ! Not much idealism ! But he 's fond of music ? Good music I mean : Wagner ?

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: He likes a brass band or a comic opera .Julie shows surpriseYou are astonished ? Oh , I forgot . He plays a little on the concertina . My dear madame , Antonin is a good chap but thoroughly matter of fact . Prosaic . JULIElaughingYou are not very complimentary to your friends .

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: What annoys me is that he should possess a treasure like you and should seem quite unconscious of its value . Ah , when I marry —

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: You are going to marry soon ?

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: I do n't know .MusinglyIf I were to meet a woman like you , a woman with whom I could discuss everything in heaven and earth , everything that raises us , makes us higher , then —

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Look for her . You 'll find her easily enough .

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: And beautiful , too . Beautiful as you are . For you are beautiful , you know . JULIEstill rallying himAre you making love to me by any chance , M. Lignol ?

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: If making love to you means yielding to an overmastering attraction — to a fascination — JULIElaughingYou certainly make the most of your time as friend of the family . But I should n't hurry if I were you . You will only be wasting a lot of pretty speeches which you could employ to greater advantage elsewhere . I have old-fashioned views on the subject of marriage .

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: Whatever they are I am sure they will be lofty and noble .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: You are too good . But you are mistaken . My view is commonplace enough . All I ask of life is that I may love my children and love my husband .

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: Your children ? JULIEquite simply , with a touch of emotionAbove everything my children . What I am going to say will sound absurd to you , but the day my first child is born will be the happiest day of my life . So you see , M. Lignol — LIGNOLinsinuatinglyDear madame , we shall meet again . JULIEsmilingAs soon as you please . Antonin comes in .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Here 's the letter . You 'll slip it into the post-box , wo n't you ? And now we 've only just time .

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: I 'm readyrising brisklyBut do n't let me drag you to the station . You 'll be leaving madame alone .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: That 's all right . Come along . I can see if M. and Madame Dupont have arrived at the same time . LIGNOLto JulieAu revoir , madame .To AntoninI am sorry not to say good-bye to mademoiselle .Antonin is puzzledTo the lady who dined with us .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Oh , Caro . I 'll say it for you . No , here she is .Caroline comes in ; and , as Lignol is saying good-bye to her , M. and Madame Dupont appear . Antonin hurriedly introducesMy friend Lignol . He has to catch this train .

sp.speaker: LIGNOL
sp.p: So sorry .He goes out with Antonin

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Ah , Caroline . There you are . I have good news for you . Your aunt is dead . Your aunt in India . She has left all her money to you and Angele . Not much . Sixty thousand francs between you . I get nothing , of course . She never could endure me . My dear girl , what 's the matter ? Come , come , you 're not going to cry because your aunt is dead ! You 've not seen her for five and twenty years . It 's the greatest stroke of luck for you . And I shall have all the trouble , as usual !A gesture of dissent from CarolineOh , yes , I shall . Your sister will have to come down from Paris .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: I thought you said she was in India .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: In India ! What are you talking about ? She is in Paris . She has never been anywhere except in Paris . What should take her to India ?To CarolineYour sister Angele will have to come down from Paris because part of the money is in land . It will be sold , of course , but still I shall have to see Angele . And that will set people talking . Lots of people do n't even know that I have three daughters .To JulieIt 's lucky for you this did n't happen before your marriage , Julie .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: Must she come , father ?

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Certainly she must . You must both be present at the lawyer 's together to sign the documents .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: I will not go the lawyer 's .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: If you refuse to go Angele will not be able to get her legacy , and she needs it .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: Well , perhaps I will go . I will think it over and consult someone . I will give you my answer tomorrow .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: As you please . And not a word about this , remember , either of you .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Very well , father . CAROLINEtaking a letter from the mantelpieceCourthezon brought this letter for you . It is about the printing work for the Prefecture . DUPONTHe reads the letterDone , by Jove ! Dumoulin gets the contract ! Dumoulin ! I expected this . I expected it . Uncle Marechal has done it on purpose , curse him !To JulieHow long have I been telling you you ought to pay him a visit . Have you been ? No . And Antonin ? Not he ! Nor his father and mother ! The old fool is offended , and this is his revenge . And if this goes on we shall never get a halfpenny of his money . Why have n't you been to see him ?

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Antonin 's parents did n't wish it .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Ah ! They did n't wish it ! Well , I have a word or two to say to Antonin 's parents , you 'll see . I do my duty , I go and call on Uncle Marechal myself . I amuse the old idiot , though it 's not the pleasantest sort of job to have to do . They did n't wish it ! I 'll show them the kind of man I am ! And you — you were fool enough to do what they told you ! I find a husband for you , a far better match than you could ever have hoped for . I do the Mairauts —

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: DUPONTalarmed , looking round herHush !

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Well , have n't I done the Mairauts ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Yes , yes . But do n't say it so loud .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: They are n't here . And if they were , Julie 's married now .Speaking lower , but with the same furyI do the Mairauts —

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Are you quite sure ?

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Am I quite sure ? Have n't I done them ? I tell you I 've done them brown ! The maid-servant comes in . SERVANTto JulieIt 's about the beer , madame .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: I 'm coming . Will you come , too , Caro ?Julie and Caroline go outDUPONTfumingBrown , by jove !

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Hush . Here they are .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: I 'm glad to hear it . Now you 'll see .

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: and Madame Mairaut come in .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Ah , you are here . Well , the wall has come down .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: I 'm not thinking about the wall .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Very likely . You have n't to pay for putting it up again .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: I 'm not thinking about the wall . I 'm thinking of something far more important . M. and Madame Mairaut , I regret to have to inform you that you are either deplorably unintelligent or else devoid of all sense of parental duty .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Indeed ! So it 's you who propose to insult us just when —

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: I am a father and I love my children . When their interests are at stake I have the sense to keep on good terms with those who may be useful to them later on .

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: MAIRAUTafter a moment 's thoughtI see . Uncle Marechal ?

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: You knew it . You did it on purpose !

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Uncle Marechal !She bursts out laughing uproariously

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: Charlotte . My dear . Do n't laugh like that .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Why should n't I laugh ? You are n't going to forbid me , I suppose ,looking full at Dupont and laughing morenor monsieur .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Well , since you take it like that , I propose to give you my view of the situation . Either you are hopelessly selfish or else you are hopelessly stupid .

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: Monsieur Dupont !

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: You hold your tongue . Leave me to deal with him .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: My dear —

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Be silent . Selfish or stupid ? Which ?Madame Mairaut shrugs her shouldersIs Uncle Marechal a man with money to leave , or is he not ?

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: MAIRAUTdecisively , after a moment 's thoughtHe is not ! DUPONTstaggeredHe is not ? But —

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: I quite understand , and you have your answer . He is not .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: He has not two hundred thousand francs ?

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: He had them . Somebody else has them now . He has lost them .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Lost them ! If this is true —

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: That is why we do n't waste our time in going to see him .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: But — I do n't understand .A pause . He controls himselfHow long ago did this happen ?

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: More than six months ago .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: More than six months ? Then you knew .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Yes , we knew .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: And you never told me .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: You did n't ask us .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: You ought to have informed me . It was dishonest .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Monsieur !

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: You have swindled me .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Swindled !

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Yes . Swindled .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Nonsense . We are as well off as you are , I hope . Our bank is worth as much as your printing business .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Most people would n't say so . As to that , by the way , I should like to ask you —

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: No , monsieur . I have nothing further to say to you . And I am now going to inform my son how you have treated us .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Madame Mairaut !

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Are you coming , Alfred ? Mairaut makes a gesture of regret and distress behind his wife 's back , and then follows her out .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: This is terrible .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Eh !Pulling himself togetherNo ! On reflection I 'm inclined to think it 's the best thing that could have happened . I regret nothing . Rather the contrary .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: I do n't understand .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Naturally ! You do n't understand . You will later .Julie comes inWe were just speaking of you . I hear your husband 's business is shaky . Is it ?

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: I know nothing about it .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: You know , I suppose , whether it is true that he got let in by the Bourdin failure ?

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Good Heavens ! What on earth do you talk about , at meals , and so on ?

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: We do n't talk at all .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Still you must have noticed whether he was anxious and preoccupied , or whether he was in his usual spirits .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: I 've no idea what his usual spirits are . I 've only known him six months .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: You 'd better ask him how things are going at once .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: What 's the good ?

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: You must ask him . You will have children some day , I suppose ? JULIEwith a sighIf it were n't for that , I think I should go and drown myself .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: That would be absurd . But we need n't discuss that now . Only , if you do n't wish your children to be beggars , keep an eye on your husband 's business affairs .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Very well . I will . Antonin comes in . ANTONINin a tone of mild reproachM. Dupont , this is very annoying . Here are my parents coming to me to complain that you have called them swindlers . I must say it 's pretty hard on me if I can n't even spend a Sunday in the country in peace . From the moment you arrive on Saturday night you begin quarrelling . And now — swindlers ! Come , come , M. Dupont , that 's not the sort of name one calls people , is it ? They are very angry , and I do n't blame them .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Oh , it was really nothing .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Maman is furious .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: That 's absurd of her . You know what it is when people begin disputing ; one word leads to another , and one says things one only half believes . However , to show how reasonable I am , I will go and make my apologies to Madame Mairaut .To Madame DupontCome , my dear : you must do the talking .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: If you put yourself in my place , you will see how unpleasant this kind of thing is . DUPONTwith dignityQuite so .He and Madame Dupont turn towards the doorANTONINcalling them backHere are M. and Madame Pouchelet . Wait .He goes to the door and calls to his parentsMaman ! They 're here , and M. Dupont wants to apologize . It was a misunderstanding , and please do n't let 's have any quarrelling before visitors .To JulieGo and help them to get their things off . Julie goes out to welcome the arrivals . M. and Madame Mairaut come in at the same moment as M. and Madame Pouchelet , Julie helping the latter to take off their wraps . M. Pouchelet is in evening dress , Madame Pouchelet in a ball dress .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: How good of you to come . My husband and I are so delighted .

sp.speaker: POUCHELET
sp.p: I promised your husband we would look in . Otherwise we should have gone straight home . The Prefet kept us longer than we wished , and we neither of us like late hours . We can only stay a moment .

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: MAIRAUTpushing forward a chair for Madame PoucheletWo n't you sit down ? ANTONINto PoucheletNaturally the Prefet was only too glad to get you to come .

sp.speaker: POUCHELET
sp.p: Yes . There is a scheme on foot for reclassifying the roads in the Department . ANTONINwith an assumption of great interestReally !

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: MAIRAUTfollowing suitReclassifying the roads . Most interesting .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: It is a matter of the greatest importance . And you , of course , are the very man to give him the necessary information . POUCHELETpompouslyI flatter myself I do know something of the subject .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: It is a question I have also had a great deal to do with . Twelve years ago I printed —

sp.speaker: POUCHELET
sp.p: I intend to make —

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: No ; it was thirteen —

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: MAIRAUTto her husbandListen , dear : M. Pouchelet is speaking .

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: Yes , yes ; I am listening .

lg.l: I intend to make an important speech on the subject at the
Council . But you will read the report in the papers .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: I should think so . We must not miss that , Julie , must we ?

sp.speaker: POUCHELET
sp.p: Oh , madame , I 'm afraid my speech is not likely to interest you .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: On the contrary . My wife only likes reading about serious subjects . Why the other day I found her reading — who was it ? that English writer : what was his name , dearest ?

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Never mind . ANTONINgoing over to Julie , summing up her pointsShe 's a wonderful little woman , my wife . Are n't you , dearest ? You are n't cold , are you ? I am always telling you you do n't wrap up enough .To PoucheletShe is charming , is n't she ? And the most devoted wife !To JulieAre n't you a devoted wife , dear ?

lg.l: Antonin , are n't you going to offer M. and Madame

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Of course .To his wifeWill you ring ? Julie rings the bell . The maid comes in almost at once with bottles of beer on a tray , and glasses . JULIEto the maidPut it there . ANTONINto Madame PoucheletMy wife is a wonderful manager . We are really hardly settled in here . Yet everything is always ready directly one wants it . May I give you a glass of beer ? The glasses which Julie has poured out are handed round . Caroline comes in .

sp.speaker: DUPONT . M
sp.p: Pouchelet , allow me to present to you my second daughter , Caroline . POUCHELETbowsMadame . ANTONINcorrecting himMademoiselle . Mlle . Caroline has always refused to marry . She prefers to devote her life to her art .

sp.speaker: MME . POUCHELET
sp.p: You are an artist , mademoiselle ? How delightful . I adore artists .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: I only paint a little on china .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: And she does it most beautifully .

sp.speaker: POUCHELET
sp.p: You must send something to our local exhibition .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Excellent ! M. Pouchelet is right . Why have you never sent anything ?

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: I only paint china plates , knick-knacks and so on .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Just for your own amusement .To PoucheletMy sister-in-law just does it to amuse herself . But I am sure if she took the trouble —

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: But I do n't do it to amuse myself .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Oh , yes , you do .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Merely to amuse yourself .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Just for your own amusement .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: And the artist can put just as much of his art into small subjects . Look at Meissonier .

sp.speaker: MME . POUCHELET
sp.p: Of course . They give just as great scope for the imagination .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: But I only copy what the people at the shop send me .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Another glass of beer , Madame Pouchelet ? It is French beer and can n't —

sp.speaker: MME . POUCHELET
sp.p: Not just now , thank you .To CarolineThe shop people , mademoiselle ?

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: Yes , madame , the people who keep the shop I work for . They pay me quite good wages for what I do .

sp.speaker: MME . POUCHELET
sp.p: I see .A silenceANTONINsotto voce , taking Caroline a glass of beerBe silent , can n't you ? CAROLINEto him , puzzledWhat is it ? ANTONINto Madame Pouchelet , leading her up to a pictureMadame Pouchelet , you understand pictures , I know . What do you think of this ? I paid a long price for it .They go on talkingCAROLINEto Madame Mairaut , in a low voiceHave I done anything I should n't ?

lg.stage: She rises and goes over to Madame Pouchelet

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: POUCHELETcoming down stage with AntoninI do n't care much about pictures unless they tell a story . What is that one about ?

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: It is an engraving of a picture by Gerard Dow .

sp.speaker: MME . POUCHELET
sp.p: Never heard of him .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: He was a Dutch painter . Seventeenth century .

sp.speaker: MME . POUCHELET
sp.p: Really . But of course you know more about these things than I do . A propos , M. Dupont , did you go to the lecture the other day on women 's rights ? POUCHELETlaughingOh , yes , ha ! ha !

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: POUCHELETto JulieI should n't be surprised if you , madame , had some sympathy with such opinions ? JULIEevasivelyI do n't know . ANTONINlaughingCome , confess , my dear . Just a little , perhaps ?

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Woman the equal of man ! JULIEmildlyWhy not ?

sp.speaker: MAIRAUT
sp.p: There are some women who would n't gain much by that .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: But not all .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Women lawyers !

sp.speaker: MME . POUCHELET
sp.p: Women doctors !

sp.speaker: POUCHELET
sp.p: Women with votes ! ANTONINlaughingWhat a joke . DUPONTlaughingWomen with votes !

sp.speaker: POUCHELET
sp.p: I call that rich .All three are convulsed with merriment

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Think of it . Women in the Chamber of Deputies !

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Women Senators !

sp.speaker: POUCHELET
sp.p: Women in the Ministry !

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: In the Chamber they would want to keep their hats on .

sp.speaker: POUCHELET
sp.p: Yesto JulieEh , Madame Mairaut ? They 'd insist on keeping on their hats as they do at the theatres .

sp.speaker: MME . POUCHELET
sp.p: And at election times they 'd go from house to house asking for votes . The modern women would enjoy that .

sp.speaker: POUCHELET
sp.p: And this parliament elected by women , what would it be like ?More laughterA Chamber of Deputies chosen by women ! JULIEa little annoyedReally , gentlemen , judging by the results you 've achieved so far by keeping the government to yourselves I do n't think you need fear that women will do much worse .The laughter dies down uneasilyPOUCHELETwith pompous solemnityI know it is the fashion nowadays to decry all our elective assemblies . But , as I am myself , in my humble way , one of the people 's representatives , I cannot allow such views to pass without protest .An awful silenceJULIEapologizingI had no intention of saying anything that could wound you , M. Pouchelet .

sp.speaker: MME . POUCHELET
sp.p: We are sure of that , dear madame . POUCHELETto his wifeAnd now , my dear , it is time for us to be going .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: You must forgive my wife 's little slip , dear monsieur .

sp.speaker: POUCHELET
sp.p: It is nothing — nothing at all .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: You must n't go like this . Another glass of beer ?

sp.speaker: MME . POUCHELET
sp.p: You are very good . It has been so close to-day .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Julie , a glass of beer for Madame Pouchelet .To herYes ; the heat this afternoon has been quite oppressive .To JulieWhere 's that beer ? JULIEwho has tried the various bottles , confusedI will send for some more . These are empty .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Really !

sp.speaker: MME . POUCHELET
sp.p: Oh , please do n't trouble . Please . No ; you really must not . We can have something when we get home .GoingOur things are here , I think .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Let me help you .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: I will come and put you on your way . POUCHELETdecliningThank you , monsieur . We know the way .

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: and Madame Pouchelet bow formally and coldly to each in turn and go out : Julie goes with them . There is a silence . Antonin paces the room irritably . Madame Mairaut grins . DUPONTto his wife , in a low voice , after glancing at the othersI think it 's time we went to bed .

lg.l: Formal bows , Monsieur , Madame , are exchanged . The Duponts go out and
So there was no more beer .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: No , dear .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: It 's intolerable .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Here are the three bottles . You told me to buy three bottles . There they are .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Nonsense . You make me ridiculous . I press Madame Pouchelet to have another glass and there is n't one . It 's preposterous .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: It is not my fault .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: I suppose you think it 's mine .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Evidently .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Besides , I have no recollection of saying three bottles .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: I assure you .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: I have no recollection whatever of it . On the contrary , I am certain I said buy four or five .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: No . Three .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: You make me look like a fool . These people will think I was laughing at them . You make me look like a fool , and that is a thing I wo n't have .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE . M
sp.p: Antonin , I was there when you spoke to Julie . You did say three bottles .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: My dear Caroline , I love you very much , but I can n't help pointing out to you that the best possible way to aggravate a dispute between husband and wife is to interfere in it either on one side or on the other . If you do n't realize that already , you may take it from me .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: If you spoke less , mademoiselle , it would certainly be better for all parties .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: Why ? What have I said ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Among other things you might refrain from proclaiming on the housetops that you are reduced to working for your living .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: There is nothing dishonorable in that .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Very likely . But one does n't talk about it .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: I thought every moment you were going to ask M. Pouchelet for an order . Not very pleasant for us , that .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: I am sorry . I did n't mean to do anything wrong .She begins to cryBut I 'm so unfortunate . I always make mistakes . ANTONINirritablyOh , for goodness sake , my dear Caroline , do n't begin to cry . There 's no earthly good in that .

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: There 's really nothing to cry about . JULIEgoing to herCaroline . Do n't cry , dear .She takes her away

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: Now , my son , we are going to say good-night .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Good-night .He kisses her absently

sp.speaker: MME . MAIRAUT
sp.p: You 're not angry with us , dear , are you ? You wanted to marry Julie , you know . Good-night .

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: and Madame Mairaut go out . Antonin , left alone , goes to the bell and rings it . The maid comes in . ANTONINto the servantPut out the lights . You can leave the two on the mantelpiece . Close those shutters .The maid does so and goes out . Julie returnsI have something to say to you .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: I am listening .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: I do not wish Caroline to remain with us any longer .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Why ? What has she done ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: You know well enough .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: No , I do not .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: She gets on my nerves .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Explain , please .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: It is not my business to give explanations . I am the master in my own house . I shall be obliged if you will arrange with Caroline to bring her visit to a close on Monday .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: But she was to stay till the end of the month . She will want to know why . What am I to say to her ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Whatever you please .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: She will be hurt .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: I do n't care about that .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: But I do care .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: If you wo n't tell her I will , in a way which wo n't admit of any misunderstanding .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: She will be angry .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Let her .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: But if you two quarrel where shall I be able to see her ? Here ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: No . I forbid you to do so .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Have you the right to forbid me ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Certainly .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Once more , because I am master here : because the husband is the master in his own house .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: That was not what you told me while we were engaged .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: I dare say .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: You have nothing more to say to me ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Yes ; I have .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: When you have opinions of the outrageous description you gave vent to this evening , please keep them to yourself .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Have n't I the right to have opinions ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Nonsense . Once for all , I have made up my mind that you shall obey me and not spoil my prospects . M. and Madame Pouchelet are people of importance . They might be useful to me , and if you offend them with your absurdities you will be wanting in your duty . Marriage is a business partnership .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Then I want to see the accounts . They say you are doing badly at the bank . Is that true ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Women know nothing about such things . You look after your household and leave the rest to me . Under the terms of our marriage the management of our affairs is in my hands . I manage them to the best of my ability . That is all I have to say to you .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: In other words , I am a business partner who has to keep her eyes shut and say nothing .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: My dear , it 's quite useless starting the lecture about women 's rights all over again . I heard it the other evening . Leave that sort of thing to old maids with beards . If I were willing to listen to you , you 'd reel off the whole catalogue of grievances against the laws which make women slaves . I know .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: No : it is not a question of law . It is a question of social usage .A pauseWhat is wrong is not that there is such and such a provision in the Code . The real evil is that our parents married us as they did marry us .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: They did as most parents do .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: And so most marriages are unhappy .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: If you really loved me —

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: But I do n't love you . That is just the point . And you do n't love me . And here we are chained to one another .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Nonsense . I not love you ?

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: No , indeed . You do n't love me .

sp.speaker: ANTONIN
sp.p: Come , come , you are talking foolishly . It 's late . Let 's go to bed . Things will be all right to-morrow morning .He goes into the bedroomJULIEsits staring in front of her for awhile : then she says to herselfNo : things will never be all right . Never . Never . ANTONINcallsAre you coming , Julie ?Julie starts as if she had been dreaming . She looks round her in a dazed wayCome along . JULIEwith a deep sigh , her face showing a mingled expression of profound disgust and sorrowful resignationI am coming .She goes slowly towards the door of the bedroom

div.head: ACT III

stage.stage: The scene is the same as in the first Act . It is September . Dupont and his wife are sitting together . There is a pile of account books on the table between them .
DUPONT [ to his wife , who is holding a paper ] You see what the accounts say . They are n't brilliant . [ To the maid who enters ] As soon as Mlle . Caroline comes in ask her to come here .

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.p: Yes , sir .The maid goes out

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: The turnover is smaller than last year .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: The profits are down to nothing . I 'm wrong . 112 francs 17 . Splendid things accounts !

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: What 's to happen next ?

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: I do n't know . One thing is certain . Things can n't go on like this .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: What are we to do , then ?

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Next year it will be worse , unless —

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Unless ?

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: The fact is the business wants new plant . At present we are using an old machine worked by hand , which I inherited from my father . We have a gas engine not worth twopence . In fact , there 's only one hope for us .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: What is that ?

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: To get fresh capital somehow .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: That 's not very likely .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Who knows ? It 's lucky for you your husband is no fool , my dear . I am going to see if I can get you out of this mess .Caroline comes inHere is Caroline . Go and find Julie . I shall want you both in a moment . I will call you . Madame Dupont goes out . DUPONTto CarolineMy dear child , I have asked you to come here because I want to have a serious talk with you . After our long arguments you have at last come to see that it is your duty to accept the legacy from your aunt . Your sister Angele is coming here .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: Coming here ?

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: But that is another matter . We will discuss that in a moment with Julie and her mother . They are in the next room . At present I am speaking only of you . All difficulties are removed now — I had a lot of trouble over it , by the way — and to-morrow at four at the lawyer 's you will receive the sum of thirty one thousand three hundred and eighteen francs and a few centimes . Ahem . My dear Caroline , you are old enough to know what you are about . Still you are not one of those undutiful children who throw aside all obedience to their fathers as soon as they are of age . You continue , I am sure , to recognize my right at least to give you advice . I have lived longer than you , I am a man of business , and I can clearly be of use to you when you want to invest your money . Have you any plans as to this so far ?

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: I had some idea —

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: May I know what it is ?

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: I would rather not say .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Not say !

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Indeed . Oh , in that case —shrug

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: You do n't mind , father ? DUPONTmuch put out , but endeavoring to control himselfNot at all . By no means . Then there 's nothing more to be said . I am a little surprised , of course ; hurt even ; greatly hurt , in fact .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: I am sorry , father .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: No matter . No matter .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: You understand —

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: I understand that you do not trust your father . That is what I understand . But have your own way . I ask nothing .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: Are you vexed with me ?

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Oh no . Not the least in the world . Only when you have given everything you possess to some religious community or other , I should like to know what you will have to live upon when you are old . I assume , of course , that it is some community you are thinking of .Caroline is silentYou admit it ?

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: No . I would rather say nothing about it .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: It is so , all the same ?

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: Please , father !

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: You wo n't give me any idea ?

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: You refuse , then ? You refuse absolutely ?

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: I have the right to do so , have I not ?

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Clearly . You are old enough .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: Do n't let us talk about it any more .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Very well .After a moment , breaking into a passionSo this is my reward ! This is the result of having sacrificed my whole life for my daughters . You do not even trust me as much as you would trust any little attorney you consulted .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: Father ! Of course I trust you . DUPONTfuriouslyHold your tongue . You are heartless and undutiful . I did not expect this .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: Please do n't be angry , father .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Angry ? Yes ; I am angry , and I have good reason .Striking the tableDamnation ! This is too much ! To have lived to be sixtytwo and be insulted like this .He strides up and down the room

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: I thought I could — I have only disposed of part of the money . DUPONTstopping shortWhat ?

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: I have only disposed of part of the money . DUPONTmollified , becoming tenderly reproachful and coming to sit by herMy dear child , why did n't you say so at once ?

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: You gave me no time .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: How much is gone ?

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: Fifteen thousand francs .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Um . That is a large sum . But the sixteen thousand that remain ?

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: I meant to ask your advice about that . DUPONTrisingAh , well , my dear , I have been thinking this over . Let 's consider what openings there are for capital . Suppose you invest it ? Gilt edged securities bring in two and a half per cent . If you take something rather more speculative , you may get four . Then there are the big industrial companies . But with them , too , there are risks to be faced . Foreign competition is more and more threatening . The struggles between labor and capital are reaching an acute phase .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE . M
sp.p: Antonin Mairaut has been to see me .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: The scoundrel ! I 'll bet he wanted you to invest the money in his bank .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: He did suggest it .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: You see . I guessed as much . You sent him about his business , I hope ?

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: I said I would think about it .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: That 's right . But what a fright you gave me . To invest your money in a bank . Nothing could be more risky . Well , as we were saying . No public companies , no industrials , no shares in banks . What remains ?

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: I do n't know .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: There remains commercial enterprize , trade . But do you know anyone engaged in trade who will let you put capital into his business ?

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: I think not .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: We must put our heads together . I confess I can think of no one . Madame Grandjean ?

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: Father ! Madame Grandjean is divorced . You know quite well I refused even to accept employment from her .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: That is true . More fool you , by the way . Still — M. Darbout ?

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: He is a Protestant .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Well , then , I do n't see . There is no one , in fact .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: But you , father . If you would do it .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: If I would do what ? Manage it for you ?

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: It is a great responsibility . I do n't know whether — What interest would you expect ?

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: Whatever you thought right , father .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Well , I will speak to your mother about it .As if suddenly making up his mindNo : I wo n't . I 'll do it . No one shall say I hesitated to do all I could for my daughter . Kiss me , my dear . I 'll do it .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: Thank you , father .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: And you would still rather not tell me what you are doing with the other fifteen thousand .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: Please , father .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Very well . You are your own mistress . I 'll have the necessary documents prepared . Do n't you worry about it . I will arrange everything beforehand . You will have nothing to do but sign .He looks at his watchThree o'clock . Now there is that other matter we have to talk of .He goes to the door and callsCome in , both of you .Julie and Madame Dupont enterSit down .When they are all seated , he saysMy dears , I wanted you all to come here that we may decide how we are to receive Angele . It is rather a difficult question . You know her life in Paris is — ahem — highly reprehensible . Ought we to let her come here ? Ought we to meet her , for instance , at the station ?

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Papa , what has Angele done ? Now that I am married surely I may know ? People always stop talking about her when I come in . I remember her quite well .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: But you were only five when she went away .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: You understand , my children , how painful this subject is both for you and for me . I will spare you the details as far as possible . It is enough that you should know , Julie , that when Angele was seventeen she was obliged to leave her home because — because —

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: DUPONTsimplyBecause she was about to become a mother .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: She went away ?

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Of her own free will ?

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: I sent her away .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Ah !

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: As I said , the subject is a very painful one . Let us get it over as quickly as possible . She is coming here to-day .He looks at his watchShe is on her way now . Her train arrived five minutes ago . Now I hope you will all of you behave with dignity , and neither be too affectionate , which would be out of the question , nor too cold , which would be unkind .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: Have you heard anything of her since she left home ?

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: And her behavior ?

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Far from what it should be , I 'm afraid . Still —

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: Father , you make too light of all this . We have heard of her three times . First when her baby died . Next we were told that she was singing at a music hall and was almost penniless . The third time we heard that she was rich , rich without working . When I think of it all I am sorry I consented to meet her .

sp.speaker: JULIE
sp.p: But she could n't get her share of the legacy unless you did . You could n't rob her of this money however you feel towards her .

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: That was what decided me . But there is no reason why I should see her here .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: I shall see her . Julie will see her . So will your mother . Why should you do differently from us ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: She was very fond of you , Caroline ; and you were fond of her . Come , come , you must not be so hard . One should have compassion for those who have suffered as she has done . CAROLINEafter a pauseVery well . I will do as you wish .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: That 's right . At the same time , I have no intention of going from one extreme to the other . There will be no question of asking her to stay , or even of inviting her to dinner . That is agreed , is it not ?

sp.speaker: CAROLINE
sp.p: Yes . And now I am going downstairs to the office .She goes out

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: You , Julie , had better go to your room .She goesIn ten minutes she will be here .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Well , I must say if she were my daughter , I should have been at the station long ago .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Do you suppose I have n't wanted to go ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Why did n't you , then ?

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: What would people say ? Everyone knows me here . On the platform I should have met a dozen people who would have asked me whom I was meeting . And , besides , all things considered , it looks more dignified to receive her here .PonderingI 've been asking myself for the last fortnight what I should say when we do meet .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Give her a kiss . The rest will come easily .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: You think I should kiss her ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: I think so , too . At the same time we must remember — how shall I put it ? Her way of life . It is a difficult question . And then what am I to say to her ? Ought I to refer to the past ? I must not seem to be forgiving her , of course . I could n't do that . I could n't possibly . On the other hand , since she is coming , I can hardly — Confound it , it 's all extremely awkward . Eh ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: I can n't advise you . DUPONTstill thinking it outOf course , she is my daughter . Still , I have not seen her for eighteen years .PeevishlyI thought I should never set eyes on her again . In the early days , when she first went away , I was terribly distressed . But that could n't last , could it ? And then , you understand — Well , well , you must advise me . I have prepared something to say , so as not to leave everything to the inspiration of the moment . If one does n't think things out beforehand , one always says too much or too little . So , as I said , I have prepared something . I even wrote it out , but I know it by heart . You can imagine how upset I am with all this . Here it is : ‘ My child ’ — I think it best to say ‘ my child . ’ ‘ Angele ’ would be too familiar and ‘ my daughter ’ too formal . ‘ My child ’ —breaking offAnd what makes it all the harder is that I 've no idea what she will say to me . Her letters are very properly expressed , very properly . Still , will she cry ? Will she break down ? Will she faint ? I do n't know . It 's impossible to know . Dear me , I wish the next half hour were over . However : ‘ My child , I thank you for having come . ’ The fact is I ought to tell you I have n't given Caroline quite a true account of how things stood . I thought it wiser not .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: It 's this way . Caroline is the one who could not get her legacy without Angele 's signature . Not the other way about .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: But you said —

sp.speaker: DUPONT
sp.p: Yes ; I did misrepresent matters a little . You see Caroline would never have agreed to meet Angele if she had known that it was she who needed Angele 's presence , not Angele hers .
