sp.p: Impossible .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I can n't help it . The contract is all ready ; the banns have been published . I have given my word .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Here 's a pretty patient ! A moment ago you were feeling for your pistol : now you want to be married in a month !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: But I must !

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: I forbid you .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You can n't mean that seriously . If this disease is not what I imagined and if I can be cured , I sha n't commit suicide . If I do n't kill myself , I must take up the ordinary course of my life . I must fulfill my engagements : I must be married .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: If my engagement were broken off it would be absolutely disastrous . You talk of it like that because you do n't know . I did n't want to get married . I have told you — I had almost a second family ; the children adored me . It is my old aunt , who owns all the property , who has pushed on the match . Then my mother wants to see me ‘ settled ’ as she says . The only thing in the world she wants is to see her baby grandchildren , and she wonders twenty times a day whether she will live long enough . Since the question first came up she simply has n't thought of anything else ; it 's the dream of her life . And then I tell you I have begun to adore Henriette . If I draw back now my mother would die of grief and I should be disinherited by my aunt . Even that is n't all . You do n't know my father-in-law 's character ! He is a man of regular high old principles ; and he has a temper like the devil . What 's more , he simply worships his daughter . It would cost me dear , I can assure you . He would call me to account — I do n't know what would happen . So there are my mother 's health , my aunt 's fortune , my future , my honor , perhaps my life , all at stake . Besides , I tell you I have given my word .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: You must take it back .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Well , since you stick to it , even if that were possible , I could not take back my signature to the contract for the purchase of a notary 's practice in two months time .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: All these —

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You wo n't tell me that I have been imprudent because I have not disposed of my wife 's dowry till after the honeymoon —

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: All these considerations are foreign to me . I am a physician , nothing but a physician . I can only tell you this : if you marry before three or four years have elapsed you will be a criminal .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: No , no , you are more than a physician : you are a confessor as well . You are not only a man of science . You can n't observe me as you would something in your laboratory and then simply say : ‘ You have this , science says that . Now be off with you . ’ My whole life depends upon you . You must listen to me ; because when you know everything you will understand the situation and will find the means to cure me in a month .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: I can only tell you over and over again that no such means exist . It is impossible to be certain of your cure — as far as one can be certain — under three or four years .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I tell you that you must find one . Listen to me : if I am not married , I shall not get the dowry . Will you kindly tell me how I am to carry out the contract I have signed ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Oh , if that is the question , it is very simple . I can easily shew you the way out of the difficulty . Get into touch with some rich man , do everything you can to gain his confidence , and when you have succeeded , rook him of all he has .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I 'm not in the mood for joking .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: I am not joking . To rob that man , or even to murder him , would not be a greater crime than you would commit in marrying a young girl in good health to get hold of her dowry , if to do so you exposed her to the terrible consequences of the disease you would give her .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Terrible ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Terrible ; and death is not the worst of them .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: But you told me just now —

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Just now I did not tell you everything . This disease , even when it is all but suppressed , still lies below the surface ready to break out again . Taken all round , it is serious enough to make it an infamy to expose a woman to it in order to avoid even the greatest inconvenience .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: But is it certain that she would catch it ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Even with the best intentions , I wo n't tell you lies . No ; it is not absolutely certain . It is probable . And there is something else I will tell you . Our remedies are not infallible . In a certain number of cases — a very small number , scarcely five per cent .— they have no effect . You may be one of these exceptions or your wife may be . In that case — I will use an expression you used just now — in that case the result would be the most frightful horrors .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Give me your advice .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: The only advice I can give you is not to marry . To put it in this way , you owe a debt . Perhaps its repayment will not be exacted ; but at the same time your creditor may come down on you suddenly , after a long interval , with the most pitiless brutality . Come , come ! You are a man of business . Marriage is a contract . If you marry without saying anything , you will be giving an implied warranty for goods which you know to be bad . That is the term , is n't it ? It would be a fraud which ought to be punishable by law .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: But what can I do ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Go to your father-in-law and tell him the unvarnished truth .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: If I do that , it will not be a delay of three or four years that he will impose on me . He will refuse his consent for good .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: In that case , tell him nothing .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: If I do n't give him a reason , I do n't know what he wo n't do . He is a man of the most violent temper . Besides , it will be still worse for Henriette than for me . Look here , doctor ; from what I have said to you , no doubt you think I simply care for the money . Well , I do think it is one 's primary duty to make certain of a reasonable amount of comfort . From my youth upwards I have always been taught that . Nowadays one must think of it , and I should never have engaged myself to a girl without money . It 's perfectly natural .With emotionBut she is so splendid , she is so much better than I am that I love her — as people love one another in books . Of course it would be a frightful disappointment not to have the practice that I have bought , but that would not be the worst for me . The worst would be losing her . If you could see her , if you knew her , you would understand .Taking out his pocket bookLook here , here 's her photograph . Just look at it .The doctor gently refuses itOh , my darling , to think that I must lose you or else — Ah !He kisses the photograph , then puts it back in his pocketI beg your pardon . I am being ridiculous . I know I am sometimes . Only put yourself in my place . I love her so .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: It is on that account that you must not marry her .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: But how can I get out of it ? If I draw back without saying anything the truth will leak out and I shall be dishonored .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: There is nothing dishonorable about being ill .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Ah , yes . But people are such idiots . Even yesterday I myself should have laughed at anyone I knew who was in the position that I am in now . Why , I should have avoided him as if he had the plague . Oh , if I were the only one to suffer ! But she — she loves me , I swear she does , she is so good . It will be dreadful for her .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Less so than it would be later .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: There 'll be a scandal .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: You will avoid a bigger one . George quietly puts two twenty-franc pieces on the desk , takes his gloves , hat and stick , and gets up .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I will think it over . Thank you , doctor . I shall come back next week as you told me to — probably .He goes towards the doorDOCTORrisingNo : I shall not see you next week , and what is more you will not think it over . You came here knowing what you had , with the express intention of not acting by my advice unless it agreed with your wishes . A flimsy honesty made you take this chance of pacifying your conscience . You wanted to have someone on whom you could afterwards throw the responsibility of an act you knew to be culpable . Do n't protest . Many who come here think as you think and do what you want to do . But when they have married in opposition to my advice the results have been for the most part so calamitous that now I am almost afraid of not having been persuasive enough . I feel as though in spite of everything I were in some sort the cause of their misery . I ought to be able to prevent such misery . If only the people who are the cause of it knew what I know and had seen what I have seen , it would be impossible . Give me your word that you will break off your engagement .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I can n't give you my word . I can only repeat : I will think it over .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Think over what ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: What you have told me .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: But what I have told you is true . You cannot make any fresh objections . I have answered those you have made . You must be convinced .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Well , of course you are right in thinking that I posted myself up a bit before coming to see you . In the first place , is it certain that I have the disease you think ? You say so , and perhaps it is true . But even the greatest doctors are sometimes deceived . Have n't I heard that Ricord , your master , used to maintain that this disease was not always contagious ? He produced cases to prove his point . Now you produce fresh cases to disprove it . Very well . But I have the right to think it over . And when I think it over , I realize the results you threaten me with are only probable . In spite of your desire to frighten me , you have been compelled to admit that my marriage will quite possibly produce no ill results for my wife . DOCTORrestraining himself with difficultyGo on . I will answer you .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You tell me that your drugs are powerful , and that for the catastrophes you speak of to happen I must be one of the five exceptions per cent . you allow , and that my wife must be an exception too . Now , if a mathematician calculated the probabilities of the case , the chance of a catastrophe would prove so small that , when the slight probability of a disaster was set against the certainty of all the disappointments and the unhappiness and perhaps the tragedies which my breaking off the match would cause , he would undoubtedly come to the conclusion that I was right and you were wrong . After all , mathematics is more scientific than medicine .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Ah , you think so ! Well , you are wrong . Twenty cases identical with yours have been carefully observed — from the beginning to the end . Nineteen times — you hear , nineteen times in twenty — the woman was contaminated by her husband . You think that the danger is negligeable : you think you have the right to make your wife take her chance , as you said , of being one of the exceptions for which we can do nothing ! Very well : then you shall know what you are doing . You shall know what sort of disease it is that your wife will have five chances per cent . of contracting without so much as having her leave asked . Take this book — it is my master 's work — here , read for yourself , I have marked the passage . You wo n't read it ? Then I will .He reads passionately‘ I have seen an unfortunate young woman changed by this disease into the likeness of a beast . The face , or I should rather say , what remained of it , was nothing but a flat surface seamed with scars . ’

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Stop , for pity 's sake , stop !

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: I shall not stop . I shall read to the end . I shall not refrain from doing right merely for fear of upsetting your nerves .He goes on‘ Of the upper lip , which had been completely eaten away , not a trace remained . ’ There , that will do . And you are willing to run the risk of inflicting that disease on a woman whom you say you love , though you cannot support even the description of it yourself ? And pray , from whom did that woman catch syphilis ? It is not I who say all this : it is this book . ‘ From a man whose criminal folly was such that he was not afraid to enter into marriage in an eruption , as was afterwards established , of marked secondary symptoms , and who had further thought fit not to have his wife treated for fear of arousing suspicion . ’ What that man did is what you want to do .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I should deserve all those names and worse still , if I were to be married with the knowledge that my marriage would bring about such horrors . But I do not believe that it would . You and your masters are specialists . Consequently you fix the whole of your attention on the subject of your studies , and you think that these dreadful , exceptional cases never have enough light thrown on them . They exercise a sort of fascination over you .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: I know that argument .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Let me go on , I beg . You have told me that one man in every seven is a syphilitic , and further that there are a hundred thousand such men going about the streets of Paris in perfect health .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: It is the fact that there are a hundred thousand who are not for the moment visibly affected by their complaint . But thousands have passed through our hospitals , victims to the most frightful ravages that our poor bodies can endure . You do not see them : they do not exist for you . Again , if it were only yourself who was in question , you might take that line well enough . But what I affirm , and repeat with all the strength of my conviction , is that you have no right to expose a human being to this appalling chance . The chance is rare , I know : I know still better how terrible it is . What have you to say now ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Nothing . I suppose you are right . I do n't know what to think .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Is it as if I were forbidding you ever to marry when I forbid you to marry now ? Is it as if I were telling you that you will never be cured ? On the contrary , I give you every hope . Only I ask a delay of three or four years , because in that time I shall be able to ascertain whether you are one of those unhappy wretches for whom there is no hope , and because during that time you will be a source of danger to your wife and children . The children : I have not spoken to you about them .Very gently and persuasivelyCome , my dear sir , you are too young and too generous to be insensible to pity . There are things that cannot fail to move you : it is incredible that I should not be able to touch or to convince you . Indeed , I feel most deeply for you ; but on that account I implore you all the more earnestly to consider what I say . You have admitted you have no right to expose your wife to such torture : but there is not only your wife — there are her children , your children , whom you may contaminate too . For the moment I will not think of you or of her : it is in the name of those innocent little ones that I appeal to you ; it is the future of the race that I am defending . Listen to me . Of the twenty marriages I spoke of only fifteen produced children . They produced twenty-eight . Do you know how many of them survived ? Three : three out of twenty-eight . Above all else syphilis is a child-murderer . Ah , yes ! Every year produces a fresh massacre of the innocents : Herod still reigns in France and all the world over . And though it is my business to preserve life , I tell you that those who die are the lucky ones . If you want to see the children of syphilitic parents , go round the children 's hospitals . We know the type : it has become classical . Any doctor can pick them out from the rest ; little creatures old from their birth , stamped with the marks of every human infirmity and decay . You will find children with every kind of affliction : hump-backed , deformed , club-footed , hare-lipped , ricketty , with heads too big and bodies too small , with congenital hip-disease . A large proportion of all these are the victims of parents who were married in ignorance of what you now know . If I could , I would cry it aloud from the housetops .A slight pauseI have told you all this without the slightest exaggeration . Think it over . Weigh the pro and the con : tot up the sum of possible suffering and certain misery . But remember that on the one side is your own suffering — and on the other the suffering of other people . Remember that . Distrust yourself .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Very well . I give in . I will not be married . I will invent some excuse . I will get it put off for six months . More than that is impossible .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: I must have three years at least , if not four .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: No , no . For pity 's sake ! You can cure me before that .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: No , no , no !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes , you can . I implore you . Science can do everything .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Science is not God Almighty . The day of miracles is past .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Oh , you could , if you wanted to . I know you could . Invent something , discover something ! Try some new treatment on me . Double the doses ! Give me ten times the ordinary ones , if you like ! I 'll stand anything , absolutely . Only there must be some way of curing me in six months . Look here , I can n't be responsible for myself after that . For the sake of my wife and her children , do something .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Nonsense .

lg.l: If only you 'll cure me , I do n't know what I wo n't do for you .
I 'll be grateful to you all my life . I 'll give you half my fortune . For
God 's sake , do something for me !

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: You want me to do more for you than for all the rest ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Let me tell you , sir , that everyone of our patients , whether he is the richest man in the land or the poorest , has everything done for him that we can do . We have no secrets in reserve for the rich or for people who are in a hurry to be cured .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Good-bye , doctor .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Good-day .

stage.stage: George 's study . To the left a window . In front of the window a desk of moderate size , facing away from the audience , and a writing chair . On the desk a telephone . To the right of the desk an arm chair , a small table with a work box and embroidery , and between the window and the footlights a deep easy chair . At the back a dainty bookcase , and in front of it a pretty table with flowers . At the back to the right a door , and , nearer , a piano and a music stool . To the left another door . Two small chairs .
Henriette is sitting by the small table and working at a baby 's cap . After a moment she holds it up on her hand .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Another little cap to send to nurse . How sweet my little Germaine will look in it ! Come , sweetheart , laugh at mother ! Oh , my love !She kisses the cap and goes on workingGeorge enters at the back . GEORGEopening the door and taking off his coat in the hallHullo ! Are you there ? Are you there ? Ha , ha , ha ! HENRIETTErising gailyOh , you know I recognized your voice .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: What a story !Kissing herPoor little darling , was she taken in , poor little woman ! Ha , ha , ha ! HENRIETTElaughing tooDo n't laugh like that !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: ‘ Hullo ! Hullo ! Madame George Dupont ? ’Imitating a woman 's timid voice‘ Yes , yes . I am here . ’ I could feel you blushing at the end of the wire . HENRIETTElaughingI did n't say ‘ I am here ’ in that voice . I simply answered ‘ Yes . ’

lg.l: ‘ Hullo , Madame George Dupont . Is George there ? ’
You were taken in ! You can n't say you were n't .
‘ George is out . Who is it speaking to me ? ’ I could hardly keep it up .
‘ Me , Gustave . ’ You thought it was , too .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: What is there astonishing in your friend Gustave telephoning ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: And when I addedimitating Gustave 's voice‘ How are you this morning , dearest ? ’ you gave a ‘ What ? ’ all flustered , like that : ‘ What ? ’

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Yes , but then I guessed it was you .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I went into fits . What a lark !He sits down in front of her on the arm of the chair close to the fireplace and watches her happilyHENRIETTEsitting down and returning his glanceWhat a funny little fellow you are !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Me ? HENRIETTEgailyDo you think I do n't understand you , after knowing you for fifteen years and being married to you a twelvemonth ? GEORGEcuriousAh ! well , go on . Say what you think of me .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: To begin with , you 're anxious . Then you 're jealous . And suspicious . You spend all your time in making a tangle of things and then inventing ingenious ways of getting out of it . GEORGEhappy to hear himself talked aboutSo that 's what you think of me ? Go on , let us have some more .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Is n't it true ? GEORGEadmitting it with a laughWell ?

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Was n't it a trap that you set for me this morning ? GEORGEin the same toneNo .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Yes ; you wanted to be sure that I had not gone out . You asked me not to go to the Louvre to-day . GEORGEinnocentlySo I did .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: See how suspicious you are , even of me .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: No ; not of you .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Yes , you are . But you have always been , so I do n't mind . And then I know at the bottom you feel things so keenly that it makes you rather afraid . GEORGEseriouslyI was laughed at so much when I was a boy . HENRIETTEgailyBesides , perhaps you have reasons for not having too much confidence in men 's friendships with their friends ’ wives . Gay deceiver ! GEORGElaughingI should like to know what you mean by that .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Suppose I had thought it was Gustave and answered : ‘ Very well , thanks . How are you , darling ? ’ GEORGElaughingWell , it is a trick that I should n't like to try on everyone .Changing the conversationBy the way , as I came in Justin spoke to me .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: He says he wants a rise .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: He has chosen a likely moment .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Has n't he ? I asked him if the sale of my cigars was not enough for him .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: How did he take that ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: He lost his temper and gave warning . This time I took him at his word . He 's simply furious .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Good .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: He 'll go at the end of the month and we shall be well rid of him . Mother will be delighted . I say , she has n't wired , has she ?

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Then she 's not coming back till to-morrow .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: If she had her way , she would never leave our little girl .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You 're not going to be jealous , are you ?

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: I 'm a little anxious . Still , if there had been anything the matter , I know your mother would have telegraphed to us .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: We agreed that she should , if there was anything since yesterday .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Perhaps after all we should have done better to keep baby with us .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Oh , are you going to begin again ?

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: No , no . Do n't scold . I know the air of Paris did n't suit her .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You still think that the dust of my papers was better for her than the air of the country . HENRIETTElaughingNo ; I do n't .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Of course , there is the square , with the smell of fried fish and all the soldiers .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Do n't tease . I know you are right .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Aha ! I 'm glad you admit that for once in a way .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Besides , nurse takes good care of her . She is a good girl .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: And how proud she is to nurse the grand-daughter of her deputy .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Father is not deputy for that district . All the same —

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: All the same he is deputy for the department .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Yes ; he is .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Ca n't you hear her talking to her friends ?Imitating the nurse 's voice‘ Have n't I had a bit of luck , neither ? Yes , ma'am ; she 's our deputy 's daughter 's daughter , she is . She 's as fat as a calf , the little duck ; and that clever with it , she understands everything . That 's not a bit of luck neither , is n't it ? ’ HENRIETTElaughingYou great silly ! She does n't talk like that at all .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Why not say at once that I can n't do imitations ?

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Now I did n't say that .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: As if mother would have engaged nurse for us if she had not been absolutely certain that baby would be well looked after . Besides , she goes down to see her every week , and she would have brought her back already —

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Twice a week sometimes .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Ah , our little Germaine knows what it is to have a granny who dotes on her .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Does n't she , though ?

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Your mother is so good . You know I adore her , too .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Runs in the family !

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Do you know , the last time we went down there with her — you had gone out somewhere or other —

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: To see that old sixteenth century chest . HENRIETTElaughingOf course , your wonderful chest .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Well , what were you going to say ?

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: You were out , and nurse had gone to mass , I think .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Or to have a drink . Go on .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: I was in the little room , and your mother thought she was alone with Germaine . But I could hear her : she was telling baby all sorts of sweet little things — silly little things , but so sweet that I felt laughing and crying at the same moment .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Did n't she call her ‘ my own little Saviour ’ ?

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Why , were you listening ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: No ; but that 's what she used to call me once on a time .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: It was that day she said she was sure baby had recognized her and laughed at her .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: One day , too , I went into mother 's room here . The door was ajar , so that she did n't hear me come in ; and I found her looking at one of the little christening slippers she wanted baby to have , you know .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Oh , yes .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: And then she took it up and kissed it .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: What did you say to her ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Nothing . I went out as softly as I could and blew a kiss to her from the other side of the door .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: When nurse 's letter came the other day , it did n't take her long to get ready and catch the 8. 59 .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: However , there was n't anything the matter .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: No ; but still perhaps she was right . Perhaps I should have gone with her .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Poor innocent little Henriette ! You believe everything you are told . Now I saw at once what was up . The nurse simply wanted to humbug us into raising her screw . I bet she did . Look here , will you bet me she did n't ? Come , what will you have ? Look here . I bet you that lovely necklace — you know , the one with the big pearl .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: No ; I should be too much afraid of winning . GEORGElaughingSilly ! I believe you think I do n't care for baby as much as you do . Why , you do n't even know how old she is ! No , no , exactly ! Let 's see . Aha ! Ninety-one days and eight hours , there !He laughsAh , when she can get on by herself , then we 'll have her back with us . Six months more to wait .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Six months is a long time to wait . When I think that if you had not put off our marriage for six months , we should have her back now !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I have told you over and over again that I only did what was right . Just consider ; how could I marry when the doctor told me I had traces of consumption ?

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Your doctor is a donkey . As if you looked like a consumptive !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Generally speaking , doctors are a bit that way , I grant .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: And you actually wanted to wait three or four years .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes ; to be quite certain I had nothing wrong with my lungs .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: You call me innocent , me ! And here were you , just because a doctor —

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: But you know it seems that I really had the beginning of some bronchial trouble . I used to feel something when I breathed rather hard — like that , only a little harder . There , that 's it . There was a sort of heaviness each side of my chest .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: It was n't anything to put off our marriage for . GEORGEgetting upYes , yes ; I assure you I was right . I should have been wrong to expose you to the chance of having a consumptive husband . No ; I 'm not at all sorry we waited . Still , those specialists — I can afford to laugh at them now . If I knew someone now who was ill , I should tell him : ‘ My dear chap , those bigwigs at forty francs a consultation — well , just do n't you consult them , you know ! ’

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: That one wanted four years to cure you !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Hang it , doctors are only men . After all they must live ; and when their consultations are forty francs apiece , why , the more the merrier .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: And some quite unknown little doctor cured you in three months !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes ; he was quite unknown . The odd thing is I have absolutely forgotten his address . I found it in the paper , I remember . I know vaguely that it was somewhere near the Halles ; but if I was to have my head chopped off for it , I could n't find it again . Idiotic , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Consequently , Germaine is six months less old than she ought to be .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: What of that ? We shall keep her so much the longer . She will be married six months later , that 's all .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Oh , do n't speak of it . It 's odious to think even now that we shall lose her some day .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Ah ! I can see myself going up the steps of the Madeleine with her on my arm .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Why the Madeleine ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I do n't know . She 'll have on a great white veil and I shall have an order in my buttonhole .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Indeed ! Pray what will you have done to get an order ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I do n't know , but I shall have one . Say what you like , I shall . What a glorious crowd there 'll be !

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: That 's all in the dim , distant future .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Ah , yes .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Yes , happily .Getting upWell , do you mind if I go and pay my visits now ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Run along , run along . I shall work hard while you are out . Look at all these papers ! I shall be up to my eyes in them before you 're downstairs . Good-bye .

sp.speaker: HENRIETTE
sp.p: Good-bye .She kisses him and goes out at the back by the rightGeorge lights a cigarette , looks at himself in the glass , and throws himself into the easy chair to the left , humming a tune . By way of being more comfortable , he moves away the writing chair and puts his feet on the desk , smoking and humming in perfect contentment . Madame Dupont comes in by the door on the left . GEORGEgetting upHullo ! Why , mother ! We had no wire , so we did n't expect you till to-morrow . Henriette has just gone out . I can call her back .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: No ; I did not want Henriette to be here when I came .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: What 's the matter ? The conversation that follows is broken by long silences .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: I have brought back the child and the nurse .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Is baby ill ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: What 's wrong with her ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Nothing serious ; at least for the moment .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: We must send for the doctor .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: I have just come from the doctor 's .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Good . I 'm not going out . I 'll wait for him .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: I have seen him .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Ah , you found him in ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: I telegraphed to him from the country , took the child to see him .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: It was so urgent as that ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: After what the nurse 's doctor had told me , I wished to be reassured immediately .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: And after all there is nothing serious .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: For the moment .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: When you got down there , how did you find baby ?

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: DUPONT Fairly well , but I sent for the doctor at once .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: What did he say ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: That you must make a change ; that the child must be brought up on the bottle .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: What an extraordinary idea .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: He told me that what she was suffering from might become very serious . So without saying anything to nurse , I made her come with me and we took the train back .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Well , what is the matter with the child ?

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: DUPONTafter a thoughtful pauseI do not know .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Did n't you ask him ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Yes . GEORGEbeginning to be anxiousWell ? A silence .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: He replied evasively . GEORGEtonelesslyHe probably did not know himself .

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: DUPONTafter a silenceProbably . During what follows they avoid looking at one another .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: But our own doctor , did n't he say —?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: It was not to him that I went .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Ah !A very long silence . Then lowerWhy ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: The nurse 's doctor had so terrified me .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Seriously ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: I asked him if the matter was too serious for our own doctor to deal with .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: What did he answer ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: That if we had the means it would be preferable to see a specialist . GEORGEtrying to pull himself togetherAnd — where did he send you ?

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: DUPONThanding him a visiting cardThere .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: He sent you to that doctor ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Yes . Do you know him ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: No — Yes — I think I have met him — I do n't know .Very lowMy God !

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: DUPONTafter a silenceHe is coming to speak to you . GEORGEscarcely daring to pronounce the wordsThen is he anxious ? MME . DUPONT . NO . HE WANTS TO SPEAK TO YOU .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: He wants to speak to me ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Yes . GEORGEresigning himselfVery well .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: When he saw the nurse , whom I had left in the waiting room , he called me back and said : ‘ It is impossible for me to continue attending on this child unless I can see its father and speak to him at once . ’ I answered ‘ Very well , ’ and gave him your address . He will not be long . GEORGEto himself in a low voiceMy poor little child !

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: DUPONTlooking at himYes , she is a poor little child . GEORGEafter a long silenceMother —

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: DUPONThearing the door openedHush !A maid comes in and speaks to her . To GeorgeIt is he !To the maidShow him in .To GeorgeI shall be there if you want me . She goes out by the left . The doctor enters by the right . DOCTORto the maidYou will let me know here when the child wakes up , will you not ?

sp.speaker: MAID
sp.p: Yes , sir . She goes out . GEORGEwith the greatest emotionGood day , doctor : you do n't recognize me ? DOCTORsimply : more discouraged than angryYou — it is you . You married and had a child after all I said to you .Almost to himselfScoundrel .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Let me explain .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: I can listen to no explanation of what you have done . A silence . GEORGEimploring himYou will look after my little girl all the same , wo n't you ? DOCTORshrugging his shoulders . LowFool ! GEORGEnot hearingI could only get my marriage put off six months .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Enough , enough . That is not my business . I was wrong even to show you my indignation . I should have left you to judge yourself . I am here only concerned with the present and the future , with the child and with the nurse .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: She is not in danger ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: The nurse is in danger of being contaminated .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: No , but — my child ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: For the moment the symptoms are not disquieting .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Thank you .More easilyAbout the nurse — you were saying — Do you mind if I call my mother ? She knows more about these things than I do .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: As you please . GEORGEgoing to the door and coming back much movedThere is one thing I should like to ask you . Could you contrive that no one — my wife — should know what has happened ? If my poor wife knew that it was I who was the cause — it is for her sake that I beg you . She is not to blame .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: I promise you that I will do everything in my power to save her from learning the real nature of the child 's illness .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Oh , thank you , thank you .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: You need not . If I tell lies , it will be for her sake and not for yours .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: And my mother ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Your mother knows the truth .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: But —

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Please , please . We have many very serious matters to discuss . George goes to the door and brings in his mother . She bows to the doctor , makes a sign to him to be seated in the armchair near the fireplace , and sits down herself on the chair near the little table . George takes a seat to the left in front of the desk .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: I have written a prescription for the child which will , I hope , improve its condition and prevent any fresh disorders . But my duty , and yours , does not stop there . If it is not too late , the health of the nurse must be protected .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Tell us what we must do .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: She must stop giving milk to the child .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: You mean that we must change the nurse ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: No . I mean that the child cannot continue to be fed at the breast either by this nurse or by any healthy nurse .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Because the child would communicate its complaint to the person who gave it milk .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: But , doctor , if the baby is brought up on the bottle it will die . GEORGEbreaking into sobsOh , my poor little girl ! Oh , my God , it 's me ! Oh ! Oh !

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Careful treatment , with sterilized milk —

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: That may succeed with healthy children , but at the age of three months a sickly child such as ours cannot be fed by hand . Such a child has all the more need of being fed at the breast . That is true ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Yes ; but —

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: In that case you will realize that between the life of the child and the health of a nurse I have no choice . GEORGEsobbingOh ! Oh ! Oh !

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Your affection leads you to express an incredible sentiment . But it is not for you to choose . I shall forbid the child to be brought up at the breast . The health of this woman does not belong to you .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Nor the life of our child to you . If there is one way to save its life , it is to give it every possible attention , and you want me to treat it in a way that you doctors condemn even for healthy children . My little one ! You think I will let her die like that ! Oh , I shall take good care she does not . Neglect the one single thing that can save her ! It would be criminal . As for the nurse , we will indemnify her . We will do everything in our power , everything but that . No , no , no ! Whatever can be done for our baby shall be done , cost what it may . But that — You do n't consider what you are asking . It would be as if I killed my child .Bursting into tearsOh , my little angel , my own little Saviour ! George has not stopped sobbing since he first began . At his mother 's last words his sobs become almost cries . His anguish is pitiable to see .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Oh , oh , oh ! My little child ! My little child ! Oh , oh !In an undertoneOh , what a scoundrel I am ! What a criminal !

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Calm yourself , madam , I beg . You will not improve matters in this way . Try to consider them coolly .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: You are right . I beg your pardon . But if you knew how much this child is to me . I lost one at the same age . I am old and widowed — I did not expect to live to see my grandchildren . You are right . George , be calm — we will show our love by being calm . Now then , we will talk seriously and coldly . But I warn you that you will not succeed in making me consent to any but the very best conditions for the child . I shall not let her be killed by being taken from the breast !

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: This is not the first time I have found myself in this situation , and I must begin by telling you that parents who have refused to be guided by my advice have invariably repented of it most bitterly .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: The only thing of which I shall repent —

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: You are evidently unaware of what the rapacity and malice of peasants such as this nurse are capable , especially against those of superior station . In this case , moreover , her enmity would be legitimate .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Oh ! What can she do ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: She can bring an action against you .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: She is far too stupid to think of such a thing .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Others will put it into her head .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: She is too poor to pay the expenses of going to law .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Then you propose to profit by her ignorance and her poverty ? Besides , she could obtain the assistance of the court .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Never ! Surely , never .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Indeed ? For my part I know at least ten such cases . In every case where the fact was proved , judgment was given against the parents .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Not in a case like this ! Not where the life of a poor innocent little child was at stake . You must be mistaken .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Many of the facts have been identical . I can give you the dates . GEORGErisingI have the law reports here .He takes a volume and hands it to the doctor

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: It is needless . DOCTORto GeorgeYou can convince yourself . In one or two cases the parents have been ordered to pay a yearly pension to the nurse ; in the others sums of money varying from three to eight thousand francs .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: If we had to fight an action , we should retain the very best lawyer on our side . Thank heaven we are rich enough . No doubt he would make it appear doubtful whether the child had not caught this disease from the nurse , rather than the nurse from the child .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Allow me to point out that such conduct would be atrocious .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Oh , it is a lawyer 's business to do such things . I should not have to say anything . In any case you may be sure that he would win our suit .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: And have you considered the scandal that would ensue . GEORGEturning to a page in the reportsHere is the judgment you were speaking of — six thousand francs .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: You can make Madame Dupont read it afterwards . Since you have the reports there , kindly give me the volume before this .George goes again to the bookcase . To Madame DupontHave you thought of the scandal ? GEORGEcoming backBut , doctor , allow me to point out : in reports of this kind the names are suppressed .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: They are not suppressed in court .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: True .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Are you sure that no paper would publish a full account of the case ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Oh , how infamous !

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: You see what a horrible scandal it would be for you .George nodsA catastrophe , absolutely .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Particularly for a notary like me .He goes to get the other volume

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: We will prevent her from bringing an action . We will give her what she wants .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Then you will expose yourself to be indefinitely blackmailed . I know one family which has paid hush-money of this kind for twelve years .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: We could make her sign a receipt .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: In full settlement of all claims ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Exactly so . Here is the volume .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: She would be only too glad to go back to her people with enough money to buy a little house and a plot of land . To a woman of her position it would be wealth . The nurse comes in .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Baby 's waked up , sir .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: I will come and see her .To Madame DupontWe will finish what we were saying presently .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Very well . Do you want the nurse ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: No , thank you . The doctor goes out .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Nurse , just wait a minute . I want to speak to you .In an undertone to her sonI know how we can manage . If we warn her and she agrees to stay , the doctor will have nothing more to say , will he ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I suppose not .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: I will promise her two thousand francs when she goes if she consents to stay on as wet-nurse .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Is that enough , do you think ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: At any rate I will try . If she hesitates I will make it more .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: All right .

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: DUPONTturning to the nurseNurse , you know that baby is a little ill .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Oh no , ma'am .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Indeed she is .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: I 've looked after her as well as possible , I know I have , ma'am .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: I do not say you have not . But she is ill : the doctors say so .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: That 's a fine story ! As if doctors were n't always finding something , so that you may n't think they do n't know their business !

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: But our doctor is a great doctor ; and you have seen yourself that baby has little pimples .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Oh ma'am , that 's nothing but the heat of her blood . Do n't you worry about it , I tell you it 's only the strength of her blood . It is n't my fault . I 've always done everything for her and kept her that clean and proper .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: No one says that it is your fault .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Then what are you finding fault with me about ? Ah , there is n't anything the matter with her . The pretty little darling , she 's a regular town baby she is , just a bit poorly ; but she 's all right , I promise you .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: I tell you she is ill : she has a cold in her head and there are sores at the back of her throat .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Then that 's because the doctor scratched her with the spoon he put into her mouth by the wrong end . And if she has a little cold , I do n't know when she caught it , I 'm sure I do n't : I always keep her that well wrapped up , she has three thicknesses of things on . It must have been when you came the time before last and opened all the windows in the house .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: But I tell you that nobody is finding fault with you at all .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Oh yes , I know . That 's all very well . I 'm only a poor country girl .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Oh , that 's all very well , it is .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: But I have told you over and over again that we have no fault to find . NURSEsticking to her ideaI never expected any unpleasantness when I came here .She begins to whimper

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: We have no fault to find with you . Only we want to warn you , you may catch the baby 's illness — NURSEsulkilyWell , if I do catch a cold , it wo n't be the first time I 've had to blow my nose , I suppose .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Perhaps you may get her pimples . NURSEsneeringOh ma'am , we country folks have n't got nice , delicate , white skins like Paris ladies have . When you have to work in the fields all day , rain or shine , you do n't need to plaster your face all over with cream , I can tell you . No offence meant , but if you want to find an excuse , that is n't much of a one .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: What do you mean ? What excuse ?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Oh yes , I know .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: What do you know ?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: I 'm only a poor country girl , I am .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: I have not the slightest idea what you mean .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Oh , I know what I mean .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Then tell me what you mean .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Oh , what 's the good ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Tell me , please ? I insist .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Oh , very well —

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Go on .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Oh , all right . I may be only a poor country girl , but I 'm not quite so stupid as that . I know what it is you want . Just because master 's cross at your having promised me thirty francs a month more if I came to Paris .Turning to GeorgeWell , and what do you expect ? Must n't I have my own little boy looked after ? And has n't his father got to eat and drink ? We 're only poor country folks , we are .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You 're making a mistake , nurse . There 's nothing at all the matter . My mother was quite right to promise you the thirty francs extra , and the only thing in my mind is that she did not promise you enough . Now I have decided when baby is old enough to have a dry-nurse and you leave us , just to show how grateful we are , to give you , er —

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: We shall make you a present , you understand , over and above your wages . We shall give you five hundred francs , or perhaps a thousand . That is , of course , if baby is in perfectly good health . NURSEstupefiedYou 'll give me five hundred francs — for myself —Struggling to understandBut you have n't got to . We did n't agree to that .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: No . NURSEto herselfWhat 's up , then ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: It is simply because baby will require more attention . You will have rather more trouble with her . You will have to give her her medicine and so on . It may be a little difficult for you .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Ah , I see . So that you may be sure I shall look after her well . You say to yourself : ‘ Nurse has an interest in her . ’ I see .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: That is understood , then ?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Very good . You will not come afterwards and complain of the way we have treated you . We have warned you that the child is ill and that you may catch her illness . To make up for that , and because you will have more trouble with her , we will give you five hundred francs when your time here is over . That is understood ?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: But you said a thousand francs , ma'am .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Very well ; a thousand francs , then . GEORGEpassing to the right behind the other two and drawing his mother asideIt 's a pity that we can n't get her to sign that .

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: DUPONTto the nurseSo that there may be no misunderstanding about the sum — you see I forgot just now that I said a thousand francs — we will draw up a little paper which we shall sign on our side and you will sign on your side .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Very good , ma'am ; I understand . The doctor comes back .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Here is the doctor . You may go , nurse ; that is all right .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .To herselfWhat 's up , then ? A thousand francs ? What 's the matter with the baby ? Has she got something bad , I wonder ?She passes to the left , between the desk and window , and goes out

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: The condition is unchanged . There is no need for anxiety .He sits down at the desk to write a prescription

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: I am glad to tell you , doctor , that you can now devote yourself to the baby and the nurse without misgiving . While you have been away we have informed the nurse of the circumstances , and agreed with her that she shall stay with us in return for a certain sum of money .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: The disease which the nurse will almost infallibly contract in giving her milk to the child is , I fear , too serious to be made the subject of a bargain , however large the sum of money . She might be completely crippled , even if she did not die of it .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: But she accepts .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: It is not only that she would be rendered incapable of serving in future as wet nurse without danger to the infants she suckled . The results of the disease to herself might be inconsiderable ; but at the same time , I repeat , they might , in spite of everything we could do , cast a terrible blight upon her life .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: But I tell you she accepts . She has the right to do what she pleases .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: I am not sure that she has the right to sell her own health , but I am sure that she has not the right to sell the health of her husband and of her children . If she contracts this disease , she will almost certainly communicate it to both of them ; and , further , the life and health of any children she might afterwards have would be gravely endangered . You understand now that it is impossible for her to make a bargain of this kind . If the mischief is not already done , every effort must be made to prevent it .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: You say : ‘ If the mischief is not done . ’ Can you not be certain ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Not as yet . There is a period of five or six weeks between the moment of contracting the disease and the appearance of its first symptoms .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: You think of nothing but the nurse . You do not think of our poor little baby . What can we do ? We cannot let her die .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: We can n't , we can n't !

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Neither can you endanger the life of this woman .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: You are not defending our interests !

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: I am defending those of the weakest .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: If we had called in our own doctor , he would have taken our side .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: I doubt it .RisingBut there is still time to send for him .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Mother ! I beg you not to go , doctor .

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: DUPONTsupplicating himOh , do n't abandon us ! You can make allowances — If you only knew what this child was to me ! I feel as if I had staved off death to wait for it . Have pity on us ! Our poor little girl — she is the weakest , surely . Have pity on her ! When you saw her tiny , suffering body , did you not feel any pity for her ? Oh , I beseech you !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Doctor , we implore you !

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Indeed I pity her and I will do everything in my power to save her . But you must not ask me to sacrifice the health of a young and strong woman to that of a sickly infant . I will be no party to giving this woman a disease that would embitter the lives of her whole family , and almost certainly render her sterile .

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: DUPONTin a stifled voiceOh , are there not enough of these peasants in the world !

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: I beg your pardon ?

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: DUPONTin the same toneI said that if she had no more children , there would only be the fewer to be unhappy .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: It is useless for us to continue this discussion .

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: DUPONTrousing herselfI shall not take your advice ! I shall not listen to you !

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: There is one here already who regrets not having done so .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes , O God , yes !

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: DUPONTmore and more exaltedI do not care ! I do not care if I am punished for it in this world and the next ! If it is a crime , if it is a sin , I accept all the responsibility , however heavy it may be ! Yes , yes ! If it must be , I will lose my soul to save our child 's life , our little one 's ! I know that hell exists for the wicked : that is one of my profoundest convictions . Then let God judge me — if I am damned , so much the worse for me !

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: I shall not allow you to take that responsibility . To enable you to do so , my consent would be necessary , and I refuse it .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: I shall speak to the nurse and give her the fullest particulars , which I am convinced you have not done .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: What ! You , a doctor , would betray family secrets entrusted to you in the strictest confidence ! Secrets of this kind !

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: The betrayal , if it is one , is forced on me by the law .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: The law ! I thought you were bound to secrecy ? DOCTORturning the pages of the volume of reportsNot in this case . Here is a judgment given by the court at Dijon : I thought that I might have to read it to you .Reading‘ A doctor who knowingly omits to inform a nurse of the dangers incurred by her in giving milk to a syphilitic child may be held responsible in damages for the results caused by her ignorance . ’ You see that the law is against you , as well as your conscience ; and I may add that , even were it not so , I should not allow you to be led by your feelings into committing such a crime . If you do not consent to have the child fed by hand , I shall either speak to the nurse or give up the case .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: You dare to threaten us ! Oh , you know the power that your knowledge gives you ! You know what need we are in of your services and that if you abandon us perhaps our child will die ! And if we give way to you , she will die all the same !WildlyO my God , my God , why cannot I sacrifice myself ? Oh , if only my aged body could take the place of this woman 's young flesh , and my poor dry breasts give to our child the milk that would save her life ! With what joy I would give myself up to this disease ! With what rapture I would suffer the most horrible ravages that it could inflict on me ! Oh , if I could but offer myself , without fear and without regret ! GEORGEflings himself into her arms with sobs and cries ofMother ! Mother ! Mother ! They weep . DOCTORto himself , movedPoor people ! Poor people !

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: DUPONTsitting down with an air of resignationTell us what we must do .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Keep the nurse here as dry-nurse so that she may not carry the infection elsewhere . We will feed the child by hand , and I beg you in all sincerity not to exaggerate the danger that will result from the change . I have every hope of restoring the baby to health in a short space of time ; and I assure you that I will use every possible effort to bring about a happy conclusion . I will call again to-morrow . Good-day .

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: DUPONTwithout movingThank you , doctor . GEORGEgoing to the door and shaking handsThank you , thank you .The doctor goes out . George comes back and goes to his mother with outstretched armsMother !

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: DUPONTrepulsing himLet me be . GEORGEchecking himselfAre we not unhappy enough , without hating one another ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: It is God who visits upon your child the sins of its father . GEORGEraising his shoulders gloomilyYou believe that : when there is not a man alive so wicked and unjust as to commit such an act !

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Oh , I know you believe in nothing .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Not in that kind of God . The nurse , who comes in by the left soon after the doctor has gone out , appears .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: If you please , ma'am , I 've been thinking : I would rather go away at once and only have the five hundred francs .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: What do you say ? You want to leave us ?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: But ten minutes ago you did n't want to .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: What has happened ?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: I 've been thinking .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Thinking ! About what ?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Well , I want to go back to my baby and my husband .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: But ten minutes ago — there must be something else .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Evidently there is something else .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: No , ma'am .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: But there must be !

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Well then , I 'm afraid that Paris does n't suit me .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: How can you tell without waiting to try ?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: I 'd rather go back home at once .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: At least tell us why .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: I have told you . I 've been thinking .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: What about ?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: I 've been thinking .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Oh , do n't say that over and over again ! ‘ I 've been thinking , I 've been thinking . ’ What have you been thinking about ?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: About everything .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Ca n't you tell us about what ?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: I tell you : about everything .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Idiot ! GEORGEstepping in front of his motherLet me speak to her .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: I know we 're only poor country folk .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Listen to me , nurse . Just now you were not only satisfied with your wages , but you were afraid we were going to send you away . In addition to your wages we have promised to give you a large sum of money at the end of your time here — and now you want to leave us , at once ! Come now , you must have some sort of reason . Has anyone been doing anything to you ?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: No , sir .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Well then ?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: I 've been thinking . GEORGEexasperatedDo n't go on repeating that silly thing ! What do you mean by it ?GentlyCome , come , tell me why you want to go away .SilenceEh ?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: I have told you .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: One might as well talk to a block of wood .

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: DUPONTcoming forwardBut you have no right to leave us .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Yes , I want to go away .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: I shall not allow you to go !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Oh well , let her go ; after all we can n't keep her by force .To the nurseSince you want to go , you shall go : but I can only say that you 're as stupid as a cow .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: I do n't mind if I am .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: I shall not pay you for the month that has just begun , and you will pay for your own railway ticket .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: We 'll see about that .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Yes , you will see . You 'll see this moment , too ! Be off with you , I do n't want you any longer . Now then !

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Do n't fly into a rage , George .To the nurseYou do n't mean it seriously , nurse , surely ?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: I would rather go back home at once and only have my five hundred francs .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: What 's that ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: What are you talking about ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Five hundred francs ?

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: What five hundred francs ?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: The five hundred francs you promised me , to be sure !

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: We never promised you anything of the sort !

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Yes , you did .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Yes , when you had finished nursing the baby and if we were satisfied with you .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: No , you said you would give me five hundred francs when I left . Now I 'm going away , so I want them .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: You will please not address me in that tone , you understand .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: You 've only got to give me my money and I sha n't say a word more .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Oh , that 's it , is it ? Very well , I discharge you on the spot . Now , then , be off with you .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: I should think so , indeed .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Off you go !

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Give me my five hundred francs . GEORGEpointing furiously at the doorTake your blasted carcase out of this . Do you hear ?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Hullo , hullo ! You speak to me a bit more politely , can n't you ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Will you get out of this , or have I got to send for the police ?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: The police ! What for , eh , what for ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: To chuck you out , you —

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Well , and what am I ? I 'm only a country girl , I am . I may be a bit stupid —

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Stupid ! I should think you were . You have no more brains than a mule .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: I may be stupid , but I 'm not —

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: DUPONTinterruptingYou have no more heart than a stone . You are a wicked woman .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: You 're no better than a thief .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Oh , a thief am I ? I should like to know why .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Because you 're trying to get money that is n't yours .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Because you are deserting our baby . You are a wicked woman .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Do you want me to put you out ?He takes her by the arm

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Oh , that 's it , is it ? So you want me to tell you why I 'm going ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Now then , out with it .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Well , why is it ? Henriette enters at the back . In the noise of the quarrel no one perceives her .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Very well , then . I 'm going away because I do n't want to catch your beastly diseases here .

sp.speaker: MME . DUPONT
sp.p: Be quiet , will you ?

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Shut up , can n't you ?

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Oh , you need n't be afraid ; everyone knows about it . Justin listened at the door to what your doctor was saying and told me what was up . Oh , I may be stupid , but I 'm not so stupid as that . I 'm going to have my money and get out of this .

sp.speaker: GEORGE
sp.p: Shut up !

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: DUPONTtaking her by the armHold your tongue , I tell you .

sp.speaker: NURSE
sp.p: Let me go ! Let me go ! I know your brat 's not going to live . I know it 's rotten through and through because its father 's got a beastly disease that he caught from some woman of the streets . Henriette , with two hoarse cries , falls to the ground in a fit of nervous sobbing . GEORGErushing towards herMy God ! Henriette eludes him and pulls herself up with disgust , hatred , and horror depicted all over her . HENRIETTEshrieking like a mad womanDo n't touch me ! Do n't touch me !

stage.stage: The doctor 's room in the hospital where he is chief physician . The doctor enters with a medical student , both in their hospital clothes , and takes off his apron while talking .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: By the way , my dear fellow , is the gentleman we passed in the passage waiting for you ?

sp.speaker: STUDENT
sp.p: No , not for me .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Then it 's my deputy . Do you know this name ? Where did I put his card ?He looks on his deskAh , here . ‘ Loches , deputy for Sarthes ’ ?

sp.speaker: STUDENT
sp.p: That 's the famous Loches .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Ah , yes , deputy for Sarthes . A regular orator , is n't he ?

sp.speaker: STUDENT
sp.p: Tremendous , I believe .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: That 's the man we want then . He busies himself a great deal with social questions ?

sp.speaker: STUDENT
sp.p: Just so .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: I suppose he wants to start an agitation in the Chamber in favor of the laws for which we have been clamoring so long . No doubt he means to post himself up first . This is what he writes : ‘ Loches , deputy for Sarthes , presents his compliments ’ etc . ... would be much obliged if I would see him to-morrow , Sunday : not for a consultation .

sp.speaker: STUDENT
sp.p: It 's very likely he has some idea of the sort .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Now that I have a deputy I will post him up , I can assure you . That 's why I have had the case from St. Charles ’ ward and number 28 brought here .

sp.speaker: STUDENT
sp.p: Shall you want me ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Not at all , my dear fellow . Good-bye .

sp.speaker: STUDENT
sp.p: Good-bye , sir . DOCTORcalling to the other as he goes outWould you mind telling them to show in M. Loches ? Thanks very much . Good-bye . The student goes out . Loches enters and bows . The doctor motions him to be seated .

sp.speaker: LOCHES
sp.p: I must thank you for being so kind as to receive me out of your regular hours . The business that brings me here is peculiarly distressing . I am the father-in-law of M. George Dupont . After the terrible revelation of yesterday , my daughter has returned to me with her child and I have come to ask you to be so good as to continue attending on the infant , but at my house .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Very good .

sp.speaker: LOCHES
sp.p: Thank you . Now , as to the scoundrel who is the cause of all these misfortunes . DOCTORvery gentlyYou must excuse me , but that is a subject on which I cannot enter . My functions are only those of a physician . LOCHESin a thick voiceI ask your pardon , but I think when you have heard me for a moment , you will agree with me . I shall not trouble you with the plans of vengeance I formed yesterday , when my poor daughter fled to me with her child in her arms after the revelation that you know . You will excuse me if I speak to you in this state — oh , I can scarcely contain my indignation ! I had intended to talk of this calmly : but when I think of that man and of his infamous conduct — the brutal , cowardly blow he has struck at me and mine — I cannot control myself — I , I —. It is abominable ! My daughter ! A girl of twenty-two ! Twenty-two ! A silence .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: I understand and respect your feelings ; but , believe me , you are not in a fit state to form any decision at this moment . LOCHESwith an effortYes , yes : I will command myself . All last night I spent in profound reflection , and after rejecting the ideas I mentioned , this is the conclusion to which I have come in conjunction with my daughter : we desire to obtain a divorce as soon as possible . Consequently I have come to ask you for the certificate which will be the basis of our action .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: What certificate ?

sp.speaker: LOCHES
sp.p: A certificate attesting the nature of the disease which this man has contracted .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: I regret that I am unable to furnish you with such a certificate .

sp.speaker: LOCHES
sp.p: How is that ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: The rule of professional secrecy is absolute .

sp.speaker: LOCHES
sp.p: It is impossible that it should be your duty to take sides with a criminal against his innocent victims .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: To avoid all discussion , I may add that even were I free , I should refuse your request .

sp.speaker: LOCHES
sp.p: May I ask why ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: I should regret having helped you to obtain a divorce .

sp.speaker: LOCHES
sp.p: Then just because you hold this or that theory , because your profession has rendered you sceptical or insensible to the sight of misery like ours , my daughter must bear this man 's name to the end of her life !

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: It would be in your daughter 's own interest that I should refuse .

sp.speaker: LOCHES
sp.p: Indeed ! You have a strange conception of her interest . DOCTORvery gentlyIn your present state of excitement you will probably begin to abuse me before five minutes are over . That will not disturb a man of my experience , but you see why I refused to discuss these subjects . However , since I have let myself in for it , I may as well explain my position . You ask me for a certificate in order to prove to the court that your son-in-law has contracted syphilis ?

sp.speaker: LOCHES
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: You do not consider that in doing so you will publicly acknowledge that your daughter has been exposed to the infection . The statement will be officially registered in the papers of the case . Do you suppose that after that your daughter is likely to find a second husband ?

sp.speaker: LOCHES
sp.p: She will never marry again .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: She says so now . Can you be sure that she will say so in five or in ten years time ? Besides , you will not obtain a divorce , because I shall not furnish you with the necessary proof .

sp.speaker: LOCHES
sp.p: I shall find other ways to establish it . I shall have the child examined by another doctor .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Indeed ! You think that this poor little thing has not been unlucky enough in her start in life ? She has been blighted physically : you wish besides to stamp her indelibly with the legal proof of congenital syphilis ?

sp.speaker: LOCHES
sp.p: So when the victims seek to defend themselves they are struck still lower ! So the law provides no arms against the man who takes an innocent , confiding young girl in sound health , knowingly befouls her with the heritage of his debauchery , and makes her mother of a wretched mite whose future is such that those who love it most do not know whether they had better pray for its life or for its immediate deliverance ! This man has inflicted on his wife the supreme insult , the most odious degradation . He has , as it were , thrust her into contact with the streetwalker with whose vice he is stained , and created between her and that common thing a bond of blood to poison herself and her child . Thanks to him , this abject creature , this prostitute , lives our life , makes one of our family , sits down with us at table . He has smirched my daughter 's imagination as he has tarnished her body , and bound up for ever in her mind the ideal of love that she placed so high with heaven knows what horrors of the hospital . He has struck her physically and morally , in her dignity and her modesty , in her love and in her child . He has hurled her into the depths of shame . And the state of law and opinion is such that this woman cannot be separated from this man save at the cost of a scandal which will overwhelm herself and her child . Very well , then , I shall not ask the aid of the law . Last night I wondered if it was not my duty to go and shoot down that brute like a mad dog . It was cowardice that prevented me . Weakly I proposed to invoke the law . Well , since the law will not do justice , I will take it into my own hands . Perhaps his death will serve as a warning to others . DOCTORputting aside his hatYou will be tried for your life .

sp.speaker: LOCHES
sp.p: And I shall be acquitted .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Yes ; but after the public narration of all your troubles . The scandal and the misfortune will be so much the greater , that is all . And how do you know that the day after your acquittal you will not find yourself before another and less lenient judge ? When your daughter , realizing that you have rendered her unhappiness irreparable , and seized with pity for your victim , demands by what right you have killed the father of her child , what will you say ? What will you say when that child one day asks the same question ? LOCHESspeaking before the other has doneThen what can I do ? DOCTORimmediatelyForgive . A silence . LOCHESwithout energyNever .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Are you quite sure that you have the right to be so inflexible ? Was it not within your power at a certain moment to spare your daughter the possibility of this misery ?

sp.speaker: LOCHES
sp.p: Within my power ! Do you imply that I am responsible ?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Yes ; I do . When the marriage was proposed you doubtless made enquiries concerning your future son-in-law 's income ; you investigated his securities ; you satisfied yourself as to his character . You only omitted one point , but it was the most important of all : you made no enquiries concerning his health .

sp.speaker: LOCHES
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: And why ?

sp.speaker: LOCHES
sp.p: Because it is not the custom .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: Well , it ought to be made the custom . Before giving his daughter in marriage a father ought to take as much care with regard to her husband as a house of business takes in engaging an employee .

sp.speaker: LOCHES
sp.p: You are right , a law should be passed .

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.p: No , no . We want no new laws : there are too many already . All that is needed is for people to understand the nature of this disease rather better . It would soon become the custom for a man who proposed for a girl 's hand to add to the other things for which he is asked a medical statement of bodily fitness , which would make it certain that he did not bring this plague into the family with him . It would be perfectly simple .
