sp.p: Yes . ANNETTEmadlyI must see him . I 'll write to him . I must see him ! If they do n't want me , I 've nothing but to kill myself ! LUCIEforcing Annette to look at herLook at me , Annette .Silence . Then in the same grave , tender voiceHave you not a secret to trust me with ? ANNETTEdisengaging herselfDo n't ask me anythingvery lowor I shall die of shame at your feet . Lucie forces her to sit down at her side and takes her in her arms .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Come , come here , in my arms . So . Put your head on my shoulder , as you used when you were tiny . Tell me , what is it ?Quite lowMy sweet , my little darling , are you terribly , terribly unhappy ? Speak out , from your heart , as you would to our poor mother . ANNETTEvery low , in tears of shameOh , mother , if you knew what your little girl had done ! LUCIEalmost nursing herTell me ; whisper , quite low , in my ear .She rises and breaks loose , then hides her face in her handsOh , you , Annette , you ! ANNETTEon her knees , her arms stretched outForgive me ! Forgive me ! My dear one , forgive me ! Oh , I deserve it all , everything you can say ; but , oh , I am so unhappy !

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: You , Annette , you !

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: Forgive me ! Do you want me to be sorry I did n't kill myself without telling you ? Forgive me ! LUCIEraising herMy dear , my dear ! You 've suffered too much not to be forgiven .

div.head: ACT II

stage.stage: The same scene . Evening . Electric light .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Now you know . I sent for you as soon as possible . MADELEINEwho is in evening dressThere is only one thing to do . Tell your husband everything and make him go to the Bernins .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: My God !

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: The doctor is a long time with him . I absolutely must go to this party .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Yes , go . But you 'll come back ?

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: As soon as I can . Do n't despair . Poor little Annette !

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Do you think —?

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: Good bye for the moment . Do n't move . Madeleine goes out , and the servant is seen giving her her cloak . Lucie , alone , walks restlessly to and fro . As she comes to the door of Brignac 's study , she stops to listen . LUCIEaloud , to herselfHow loud the doctor 's speaking . One would think they had quarrelled .

div.stage: Fresh pause . The study door opens . Enter Hourtin and Brignac .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: I can assure you , Dr. Hourtin , that I have reached years of discretion .

sp.speaker: HOURTIN
sp.p: It was my duty , sir , to speak to you as I have done . BRIGNACshewing him to the door , drilyI am obliged to you .

sp.speaker: HOURTIN
sp.p: I have something else to say to Madame Brignac .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: About me ?

sp.speaker: HOURTIN
sp.p: About herself and the children ; but if you object —

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: I hardly imagine it is indispensable .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: What is it ? Dr. Hourtin , I beg you will tell me what you think I ought to know .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: I have n't time to waste over this subject . I repeat I am exceedingly busy , and I have to make a speech this evening . You must excuse my leaving you . Good bye .

div.stage: Hourtin bows . Brignac goes out , slamming the door of his study .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: I trust you will forgive my husband if he has annoyed you .

sp.speaker: HOURTIN
sp.p: A doctor cannot be annoyed at the symptoms of a disease . I would no more be indignant at M. Brignac 's temper than bear malice against him for having fever in an attack of pneumonia .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: You wanted to speak to him . Is there something about the children ?

sp.speaker: HOURTIN
sp.p: If you see that the children are treated as your own doctor and I have prescribed in our consultation , I am confident that their condition will improve . But I have something more to say to you yourself . Not long ago I was called in to a married couple , one of whom was a victim to morphia and refused to give up the use of the poison . The children of the marriage were degenerate , and there was every reason to think that should others be born they would be even less healthy than the first . I had to inform the other parent concerned of the facts , in order , if possible , to discover some means of cure . Towards you I have the same duty . With the difference that here the poison is alcohol instead of morphia , the cases are identical . Like my other patient , M. Brignac refused to listen to me ; and although his obstinacy is due to his poisoned condition , I confess I was unable , in spite of a physician 's philosophy , to see without irritation the way in which he is rushing to ruin , intellectual and physical . Now your nerves are strong . I was unwilling to go away without speaking to you .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: My children ?

sp.speaker: HOURTIN
sp.p: Your children are suffering from a nervous complaint which was born with them .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: As the result , you mean , of their father 's intemperance ? Our own doctor and another besides have already told me the same thing .

sp.speaker: HOURTIN
sp.p: They should have begun by telling M. Brignac .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: They did .

sp.speaker: HOURTIN
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: He listened no more to them than he did to you .

sp.speaker: HOURTIN
sp.p: Is he not fond of the children ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: In his own way he is . But he will never change his way of living .

sp.speaker: HOURTIN
sp.p: So much the worse for him .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: He did try once . He was incapable of work and became sad , weak , restless .

sp.speaker: HOURTIN
sp.p: Like a morphinomaniac deprived of his drug .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: To his mind the experiment was decisive . He simply cannot study a brief or speak in court without the help of his usual stimulant . He thinks it does him no harm .

sp.speaker: HOURTIN
sp.p: He has only to look at the children .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: What he says is that at their age he had nervous convulsions , and that now he is perfectly well .

sp.speaker: HOURTIN
sp.p: Precisely . He received from his father a legacy that he has transmitted to them in a graver degree . His father drank , but his life was the healthy , active , open air life of a peasant , and his power of resistance greater because he probably did not inherit a morbid tendency . Your husband 's life is sedentary and feverish . Moreover , he does inherit the tendency . You tell me that he had convulsions in infancy ; yesterday he said he was a backward child . These are symptoms just as much as his desire for drink and his irritability . He had a taint at birth that he has increased . His children suffer from a cumulative degeneracy . The grandfather drank , the son suffers from alcoholism , the children are nervous invalids .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Horrible .

sp.speaker: HOURTIN
sp.p: You must use all your influence with your husband to cure him .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: He wo n't listen to me .

sp.speaker: HOURTIN
sp.p: You must insist . You must make him see his duty as a father .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: It would be so useless that I shall not even try . HOURTINrisingThen I have only one further piece of advice for you both : do n't have any more children .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: No more children ?

sp.speaker: HOURTIN
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: HOURTIN
sp.p: Because it is to be feared that any you might now have would be more diseased than the first .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Is that certain ?

sp.speaker: HOURTIN
sp.p: In medicine there are no certainties ; only probabilities . The chances are , perhaps , five to one that I am right . Would you venture to give any creature so doubtful an existence ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: I ! No , indeed . Most likely you have said as much to my husband . Wo n't he believe you ?

sp.speaker: HOURTIN
sp.p: You must make him realize that the responsibility of having a child , great as it always is , becomes terrible when , so far from its being born into normal circumstances , it runs the risk of going into the world worse equipped than usual . To give birth to a child doomed to unhappiness or likely to be an invalid or incapable of growing up is like crippling someone . It is as much a crime as robbery or murder . Children ought to be deliberately and soberly brought into the world by parents healthy enough to give them health and of sufficient means to ensure their complete development . You must forgive me . When I get on this subject I hardly know how to stop . But really there is so much unavoidable misery and distress that we ought not to add to the sum of general suffering for which there is no remedy .

div.stage: Enter Madeleine . She wears an opera cloak and a mantilla over her evening dress . During the following scene Josephine helps her off with her things .

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: How do you do , Dr. Hourtin ? I 'm so glad to find you still here . I 've only just been able to get away from the party . I had to go . There 's nothing serious the matter with the children , I hope ?

sp.speaker: HOURTIN
sp.p: Nothing serious . With the care of a mother like theirs , I have every confidence . Now I was just going . Good bye .

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: Good bye . Thank you .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: I 'm extremely grateful to you , Dr. Hourtin .

sp.speaker: HOURTIN
sp.p: Do n't mention it . Good bye , good bye .He goes out

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Oh , Madeleine !

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: What is it ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Do you know why the children are ill ? Because of Julien 's intemperance .

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: My poor darling ! But you knew that before . Our doctor said so ; and when they went to Paris with me , the man there said the same .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: I tried to make myself believe it was n't true .

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: And Annette ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Has anything fresh happened ?

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: Yes ; the Bernins have announced Jacques ’ engagement to his cousin . They want to put an end to the business . People were talking of the engagement this evening .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Ah ! And they 're still going away this evening .

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: At ten o'clock . How does she take it ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: She is in her room , waiting as though she expected something . She said just now she knew the Bernins would not go this evening . What can she hope ?

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: We must tell her about the engagement . She must n't be left to hear of it from strangers .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: No , no .

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: And your husband ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: He 's working in there . There 's to be a political meeting , a smoking concert or something , after the dinner at the Prefecture to-night . He heard at the last moment that he was expected to speak , on the budget of the Department , I think . I do n't know exactly . Anyway , he 's there .

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: Fetch Annette , then .

lg.stage: She goes out . A short silence . Then she calls outside

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: Where is she ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Gone ! She 's left a note . She 's gone to look for him . Quick ! Your carriage is here . Go and find her . Help her !

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: Gone !

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Yes . Quick ! Go ! Madeleine goes out . Enter Brignac .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: What is all this noise about ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Julien , I 've something very serious to say to you . A disaster has fallen on us .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: The children !

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: No ; it 's about Annette .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Is she ill ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Not ill , but in cruel , horrible grief .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Grief at her age ! A love affair , eh ? She 's been jilted ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: That 's it .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Whew ! I breathe again . You frightened me . Not so very serious .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Yes ; it is . My dear , you must listen with all your heart and with all your mind — and be kind .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: But what 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Annette has fallen in love with a scoundrel who has deceived her . The poor child committed the mistake of trusting him completely . He promised to marry her and took advantage of her innocence to seduce her .LowUnderstand me , Julien : she is going to have a baby in six months .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Annette ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Annette .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Impossible . It 's —

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: It was she who confessed to me . She is sure of it . BRIGNACafter a silenceWho 's the man ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Jacques Bernin .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Jacques Bernin !

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Yes . BRIGNACfuriousHere 's a fine piece of business ! Ha , at the moment of my election , too ! Magnificent ! Oh , she 's done me to rights , your sister has ! All 's up with me now . We may as well pack our trunks and be off .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: You exaggerate .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Do I ? I tell you if she had been caught stealing — stealing , do you hear ?— it would n't have been worse . Even that would have compromised me less — thrown me less absolutely out of the running .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Leave that till later . Now the thing is to save her . You 'll go tomorrow morning , wo n't you , Julien , and find this fellow ? Make him see what an abominable crime it would be for him to desert our poor little girl .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Much you know him , M. Jacques Bernin . But I do ! He 'll laugh in my face . His one idea is to get on in the world . Why , he was talking of his engagement to Mademoiselle Dormance two months ago and chortling over her shekels . Good lord , what a man for your sister to hit upon !

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: But you wo n't abandon her ?

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Yes ; I 'm in a nice place . Who 'd have thought it ? So this is the thanks I get for all I 've done for her !

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Do n't fly into a rage !

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Her ! her ! A child brought up in the strictest principles , brought up at home here by you and me , not allowed to read novels or go to the theatre ! She has n't even the excuse of having been to a boarding school . Why , sometimes we could hardly help laughing at her ignorance of life .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Perhaps if she had been less ignorant , she would have run less risk . BRIGNACbreaking outThat 's right ! Now it 's all my fault !

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Do n't get into a passion !

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: I shall if I like ! And I think there 's some reason , too ! Annette !

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Annette is only a victim . BRIGNACshoutingA victim ! I tell you there 's only one victim here ! Only one ! And do you know who ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: You , I suppose .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Yes ; it is . Look here . Ca n't you see the jokes that will be made about me , the ironical congratulations — me , the apostle of repopulation ? Ha , they 'll say that if I do n't give an example myself , my family does !

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Julien , Julien , please !

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Just when I thought I had done with vegetating as a provincial lawyer , when my patience and ability had got me accepted as candidate !

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: You might not have been elected .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: I should have been ! Even if it were not me , our side would win . Once in the Chamber , I should have done with this wretched obscure existence .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: And then ?

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Then ? A deputy gets any amount of work , and wins his cases , too ! Judges listen very differently to a man who any day may become Minister of Justice . It means something to them . And now this catastrophe ! I tell you that here , at Chartres , it spells ruin .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: How you exaggerate ! Who 's to know ?

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Who 's to know ? Next Sunday every person in the town 'll be talking of it . And my political opponents , do you think they 'll scruple ? Not only them either . M. de Forgeau and his committee wo n't give the electors the chance to turn me down . Within a week I shall be shewn the door . You see ! It 'll be lucky if no one insinuates that I seduced the girl myself !

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: This is a provincial town ! This is Chartres !

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: So when an unhappy woman is seduced by a scoundrel , her shame , if shame there is , falls on her whole family ! Is that the system you uphold ?

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Society must defend itself against immorality . Without the guarantee of social punishment , there would soon be hardly any except illegitimate children .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: If anyone is guilty , two are . Why do you only punish the mother ?

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: How should I know ? Because it 's easier .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: But you can n't sit still and do nothing . You must do something ! You 're the head of the family .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Something ! Something ! What ? The only logical thing I know is to take a pistol —

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Julien !

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: And go coolly and put a bullet through the man 's head . No ? A crime , is it ? Ah , if we lived in an age with a little more guts !As if to himselfNo ; I 'm not sure it 's not my duty to go and do justice myself

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Julien , you 're not dreaming of that !

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: And why not ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Think of the scandal , and then —

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: And then I should be tried for murder ? Well , do you think I 'm afraid of that ? What then ? I should defend myself , and I can tell you not many people have heard such a speech as I should make ! Think of the effect on the jury ! I should be acquitted , and the public would cheer till the court had to be cleared .A pauseHe 's in luck 's way , the brute , that I 've too much respect for human life . If I were n't a bit old fashioned — ha , so much for him .A pauseNo , no ; the weak point in these folk is their pocket . That 's what I 'll go for . That 's it . We 'll bring an action , an action for the seduction of an infant .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Publish her shame like that !

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: He 'll have his share of it . I 'll make him sing another tune , so I will . We 'll ask twenty , fifty , a hundred thousand francs damages ! It 'll be a dowry for Annette . Yes ; we can do that , an ordinary civil action , or else , if we like , prosecute him criminally . I could shew you the law about it ; it 's all in the reports . And besides , the way I 'll conduct the case , the papers will boom it sky high .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: You can n't surely want to have the papers talking about us , printing poor Annette 's story , discussing her honor ?

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Reflecting on me , too . If only we were n't related !

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: We should be just as much dishonored .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: If you had n't made me take Annette to live with us when your parents died , none of this would have happened .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: It was you who suggested it to me !

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: I know I did . All the stupid things I 've done in my life — not that there have been many — come from my having too good a heart . All people from the South have ; we can n't think twice before doing a kindness . So much the more reason why you should have looked after her carefully .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Oh , it 's too much ! When you yourself wanted her to make friends with the Bernins !

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Because I hoped that old Bernin would be useful to us !

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: You always kept urging Annette to go to them .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: So it 's all my fault , is it ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: I do n't say that , but I must shew you that I 'm not so culpable as you make out . What are we going to do ?

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: In any case Annette can n't stay here .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Good heavens , where can she go ? Madeleine can n't have her . Perhaps our old nurse , Catherine —

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: If she went to Madeleine or Catherine , it would be exactly as if we kept her here . The important thing is that no one should know anything about it . She must go to Paris , to some big town , till the birth of her child .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: It 's not possible .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: The only thing not possible is to let it be known , to keep her at Chartres . Ca n't you imagine what it would be like for her if we did ? Think of her going to a concert or to Mass when her condition became evident ! She would n't be able to go out of the house without being exposed to insult and insolence . And the way our acquaintances would look at her ! Why , it would be purgatory .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: And everyone will welcome M. Jacques Bernin .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Of course they will . And when the child is born , what then ? I 'm not thinking of the expense : fortunately for her she has us to fall back on , so she would n't starve . Suppose she put the baby out to nurse ? Afterwards she 'd have to keep it with her — imagine what people would say ! She might pay for it to be brought up elsewhere , but that 's only a way of deserting it . She would never be able to marry . All her life she would be a pariah . No ; the only thing is to send her away .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Send her away — where to ?

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: How should I know ? We 'll find some place . There are places for that at Paris . Yes ; I remember now , special places . We 'll pay whatever is necessary . Establishments where you 're not required to give your name at all . The difficulty will be to find a plausible reason of Annette 's absence . However , we 'll find one .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: And the child ?

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: The child ? She can do what she likes with that . You do n't suppose I 'll have it back here with her , do you ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Then that 's what you 're proposing to do ?

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: That 's what we must do .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: How does one get into these places you were speaking of ?

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: I do n't know exactly . I 'll find out . Do n't worry . If necessary , I 'll go to Paris and take the proper steps . Of course without saying that it 's to do with anyone I know .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Of course .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Of course . LUCIErising and touching him on the shoulder as she passesYou are a fine fellow . BRIGNACmodestlyOh , come ; only a little thought was wanted .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: I think you have no conscience at all .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: What do you mean ? You speak as if I were a monster .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Nothing but respect for public opinion .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Respect for public opinion is one form of conscience .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: The conscience of people who have n't got any !

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Anyway , one can n't do anything else .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Ca n't you imagine what my poor darling 's life would be like if we did what you said ? Turned out of here —

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: No , no ; not turned out .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Sent away unwillingly , if you like , coming to this place , suddenly thrust into contact with all the sadness and the misery and the vice of Paris ! Think of her waiting all those months , in the midst of the women there , while a poor little creature is growing into life that she knows beforehand is condemned to all the risks and cruelty suffered by children whom their mothers abandon ! And when she is torn with the torturing pain that I know so well , at that moment of martyrdom when a woman feels death hovering over her bed and watching jealously for mother and child , when the full horror of the sacred mystery she has accomplished is on her , then she 'll only have strangers round her ! And if her poor eyes look round , like a victim 's , perhaps for the last time , for a friendly glance , if she feels for a hand to press , she will only see round her bed unknown men performing a duty and women carrying on their trade . And then ? Then she must resist her highest instincts , stifle the cry of love that consoles all women for what they have gone through , and say she does n't want her child — look aside , and say : ‘ Take him away ! I do n't want to see him . ’ That 's the price for which she will be pardoned the crime of someone else ! That 's your justice ! Justice ! Social hypocrisy rather — that 's what you stand up for . Nothing but that . And that 's why , if Annette stayed to bring up her child here , she would be an object of reproach ; whereas , if she is confined secretly in Paris and gets rid of the baby , nobody will say anything . Let 's be frank about it . If she had a lover , but no child , she would be let off . It is n't immorality that 's condemned , but having children ! You cry out for a higher birth rate , and at the same time you say to women : ‘ No children without marriage , and no marriage without a dowry . ’ Well , so long as you do n't change that , all your circulars and your speeches will only succeed in arousing laughter of pity and of rage !

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Well , is it my fault ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: No ; it 's not your fault . It 's the fault of all of us , of our prejudice , our silly vanity , our hypocrisy . But you stand up for it all and justify it . You have the typical window dressing , middle class virtues . You publicly preach the repopulation of France , and then find it in your conscience to get rid of a child whose only fault is that its parents had it without first going through a stupid ceremony , and without the whole town being told that Monsieur X and Mademoiselle Y were going to bed together !A pauseGo and make your speech . Go and defend the morals of society . That 's about what you 're worth .

div.stage: Enter Madeleine .

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: She 's not come back ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: No . Have n't you seen her ?

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Since you take it like that , then , you will kindly find another home than my house for your sister from now onwards .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Ah , yes ; say it outright ! You long to get rid of her ! BRIGNACtalking all the time while he goes into his study and comes back with his portfolio , hat , and coatI 'm off . It 's too much ! Yes ; I 'm off ! And for my part , I refuse to be the victim of your sister 's pranks ! LUCIEto herselfWretch ! wretch !

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Do what you like , but I wo n't have that sort of thing here .He goes out

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: I do n't know which way she went nor where she is .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: You 've been to the Bernins ?

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: They were dining out .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Did they leave the town by an afternoon train ?

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: I do n't know .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Oh , I 'm afraid .

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: Annette must have known where they were dining , because I got to their door before she had time to get there herself .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: You should have gone to the station .

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: I made up my mind to , but then I saw that I should n't have time before the train went . So I thought she must have come back .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Here she is ! Thank God !

div.stage: Enter Catherine and Annette .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: I will ! I will tell ! So as they may stop you trying again . Annette , her teeth clenched , her eyes fixed , shrugs her shoulders . Throughout the ensuing scene no tear comes to her eyes .

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: In heaven 's name what has happened ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: You 're here , you 're here !She tries to take Annette in her arms

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: Let me go ! Let me go !She picks up her hat and coat , which she has thrown on to a chair , and sits down , hard and reticent

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: What is the matter ? What have you done ? ANNETTEin a broken voiceI wanted to put an end to myself . Catherine stopped me .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: To kill —

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: Annette !

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: And us , had you forgotten us ?

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: My death would have brought less trouble on you than my life will .

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: Catherine , what has happened ?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: I was getting out of the train . I saw her start to throw herself under the wheels . MADELEINE and LUCIEterrifiedOh !

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: You 'll be sorry one day you stopped me .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: You hear her ! That 's the way she 's been going on as we came back , all the time she was telling me her story .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Swear you 'll never try again , Annette .

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: How can I tell ?

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: Was she alone ?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: No . When I saw her , she seemed to be having a dispute with M. Bernin 's family . I stopped to watch . Then M. Jacques got into the train and Annette stood there crying ; and just as the train went away , she gave a cry and ran to try and throw herself under the wheels . I caught her by her dress and brought her away ; and I would n't leave her till I knew she was back here and I had told you what she 'd done .

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: All right . Do n't let 's speak about it . I tried to kill myself and I failed . If they saw me , no doubt they shrugged their shoulders .

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: You went to wait for them at the train ?

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: No . I knew where Jacques was dining — at a restaurant — a farewell party . His parents were having dinner at the station . I went to the restaurant and asked for him , like a girl off the streets . I could hear his friends laughing and joking from where I was , when the waiter took my message .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Did he come ?

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: Yes . He told me afterwards he thought it was some woman from a cafe chantant who sent for him . Oh !

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: And when he saw that it was you ?

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: He took me into the street , so that I should n't be recognized . That 's where we had our talk . The passers-by laughed and made horrible jokes .

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: And then you told him ?

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: You could n't guess what he answered : that it was n't true .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Oh ! ANNETTEstill tearlesslyThen he lost his temper and said he saw through my game ; that I wanted to force him to marry me because he was rich . Much he spared me ! I tried to put my arms round him : he threatened to call the police . Then I cried , I implored him — I asked him to come with me tomorrow to a doctor to prove I was n't lying . He answered quite coldly that , even if it was true , there was nothing to prove that it was him . Ah , you can n't believe it , can you ? It 's too much ! I could n't have , unless I had heard it with my own ears ; and how I could without dying I do n't know . You do n't know what depths of shame and cowardice I sunk to . Then he looked at his watch , saying he only had time to catch the train . He said good bye and dashed off to the station . I had to half run to keep up , crying , and begging him not to desert me — for the sake of his child , of my happiness , my love , my very life ! Horrible ! Horrible ! Loathsome ! And how ridiculous ! I had him by the arm . I could n't believe that was the end . At the entrance to the station he said , brutally : ‘ Let me go , will you ? ’ I said : ‘ You sha n't go . ’ Then he rushed to the train and got into the carriage , nearly crushing my fingers in the door , and hid behind his mother ; and she threatened , too , to have me arrested . Gabrielle sat there , looking white , and pretending not to notice and not to know me . Catherine 's told you the rest . A silence .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: You must swear , Annette , never to think again of suicide .

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: I could n't swear sincerely .

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: You must be brave , now that you know what life is , brutally as it has been revealed to you . Almost all the women you think happy have gone through an inner catastrophe . They make themselves forget it because their very tears give out . Suffering is reticent , and they conceal theirs . But there are few women whose lives have not been broken , few who do n't carry within them the corpse of the woman they would have wished to be .

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: You say that to console me . I do n't believe it .

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: It 's the truth ; and I 've learnt it by experience .

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: I 'm tired of life . I feel as if I were a hundred .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Keep up your heart . We wo n't desert you .

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: What can you do ? I shall be turned away from here .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: If you are , I 'll go with you .

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: And your children ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: I 'll take them , too .

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: He 'll fetch them back . Besides , what should we live on ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Ah !

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: You see . You can n't do anything either , Madeleine , for all your love . Your husband would n't let you take me in . Nor you either , Catherine . You could n't afford to . Well , then ?

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Eh ! eh ! Fresh silence .

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: What a terrible thing life is !

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: For all women .

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: Not for anyone as much as for me .

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: You think so , and that 's why you think of dying . Well , I 'm alive . You see me laughing now and then . If you only knew !

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: And what about about me , Annette ?

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: You have your children to console you .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: It 's they that make it hard for me .

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: For other women it 's a refuge to have children . What will it be for me ?

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: You think that I am happy , Annette ?

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: You have a husband who loves you , you 're rich , you can afford to dress beautifully , you go everywhere , and everyone wants to have you . That 's some happiness , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: That 's all you see . If you only knew what you do n't see !

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Do you think being a mother has made me happy ?

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: I know you 're poor . You have to work , to work hard , to bring up your children ; but you can look the world in the face and love them .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: If you knew !

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: Then you must know ! Even Lucie does n't know what I 'm going to say . You think I 'm happy because the money my godmother left me enabled me to marry the man of my choice , a man who was well off . Listen , then . My husband married me because I was good looking . He wanted a son . I gave him one , but my child cost me his love . You can n't be a wife and a mother at the same time . I lost my elegant figure , I was ill , I suffered the woes that woman 's flesh is heir to and — he left me for another woman ! Do n't be too quick to condemn worldly women who shrink from motherhood , Annette . Man 's baseness is such that they must often choose between their husbands and their children . And if some choose their husband , let those who have never loved throw the first stone at them ! I felt that if I nursed my baby I should lose my husband for good , and to win him back I put my child out to nurse . He died , Annette ; and I have the agony of thinking that if I had kept him with me he would be alive . Do you understand ? It 's as if I had killed him . Now I do n't mean to have another child . I lead a worldly life , laughing , dining out , going to parties , because that 's what my husband wants , and that 's how he loves me . I shall have a lonely old age . My arms are empty — mine , whose joy would have been to rock my children to sleep in them — and I 'm ashamed of what I 'm doing . I despise myself . You 'd think I 'd paid enough for my husband 's love , would n't you ? Oh , no . He 's gone to Paris , ostensibly on business , really to another woman . I know it . I pretend not to know because I 'm afraid of forcing him to choose between her and me . That 's my life , Annette . Many women whom you think happy live like that .

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: Poor Madeleine !

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: And I . One of my little girls is an invalid , the other is ailing . Perhaps she 'll die .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Two of mine died of want .

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: I do n't want to have another child for fear that my husband would leave me altogether . A divorce , if I got one , would leave me a kind of half-widow and make my girl an orphan .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: If I had any more , it would only mean taking away food from those who have n't enough as it is .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: I 'm guilty enough already . Two children of suffering owe their existence to me .

lg.l: Think of my torture ! I adore my husband : when he comes back
I long to feel myself in his arms and I dread the consequences .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Mine will leave me if I have another . And then what would become of me , all alone with all my children ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Your children who are grown up will support you , Catherine .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: Those who are grown up ! Grown up ! I 've just been hearing about them . Edmond is in hospital , ruined for life by going into what they call ‘ a dangerous trade ’ because he could n't get work in any other . There are too many workmen . My daughter , she 's on the streets .SobbingOh , it 's too much ! There 's too much misery in the world !

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: Yes , there 's too much misery !

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: And I thought I was the most miserable !

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: There 's too much unhappiness !

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: The children of poor folk are unhappy , all of them , all .

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: The child of an unmarried woman , too , is born only to suffering .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Children who are born sickly or ill ought not to be born at all .

sp.speaker: CATHERINE
sp.p: You see , Annette , we must bear it . God 's given us eyes ; it 's to cry with .

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: To cry with ! The four women cry silently . Catherine is in Madeleine 's arms . Lucie has her head on Annette 's lap . CATHERINEmaking ready to leavePlease to forgive me .

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: We have the same troubles .

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: Yes ; we have the same troubles .

lg.l: Yes ; whether one 's rich or poor , when one 's a woman —
Annette kisses Catherine . Catherine goes out .

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: I must go , too . Your husband will be coming back . LUCIEto herself , terrifiedMy husband coming back — coming back !

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.p: I wo n't see him . Madeleine , you 're alone ; take me with you !

sp.speaker: MADELEINE
sp.p: Yes . You can come tomorrow , Lucie . We 'll talk then .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Yes .SuddenlyHere he is . Go out that way . She pushes them out through Annette 's room . After a moment Brignac comes in , flushed and happy .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: What , still up ! Aha , my dear , I 'm going to be elected ! Absolutely certain , I tell you . Here , I 've brought you a bunch of roses . LUCIEwithout listeningThank you . So you 're going to turn Annette out ?

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: I 'm not turning her out . I simply ask her to go somewhere else .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: I shall go with her .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: You 're going to leave me ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: You do n't love me any more , then ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Ha . Another story beginning . Since when ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: I 've never loved you .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: All the same you married me .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: I did n't love you .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: This is nice news . Go on .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: You 're only another victim of the morals you were championing just now .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: I do n't know what you mean .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: When you asked me to marry you I was tired of waiting in poverty for the man I could have loved . I did n't want to become an old maid . I took you , but I knew you came to me because the girls with money would n't have you . You were on the shelf , too . I made up my mind to try and love you loyally .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Well , then ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: The first time I was going to have a child you left me for other women . Since then I have only put up with you . I was too cowardly not to . You may as well know it . I wanted my first child ; the others I 've had only because you made me . Each time you left me — I was so ugly ! Yes ; ugly through you ! You left me at home , alone , dreary , repulsive , to come back from the arms of some prostitute , full of hypocritical solicitude for my health ! After the fatigue of nursing I begged for a rest , to have a breathing space , so that I might have some life of my own ; and when I demanded only to have children at my own wish , you laughed like a self-satisfied fool . Oh , your fatuous pride , your base egoism , your utter want of thought for the future of your children and the life of your wife ! So you forced on me the labor and the agony and the danger of having another child . What did it matter to you ? It flattered your vanity to make merry with your friends and give yourself the airs of a fine fellow . Idiot !

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: I 've had enough of this . You 're my wife !

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: I wo n't be your wife any more . I wo n't have any more children .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Pray why ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Did n't Dr. Hourtin tell you anything ?

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Yes . All right . I 'll do what he said . There , does that content you ? Come to bed .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: You have n't looked at my roses . Come , is n't he a loving husband , your little Julien ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Leave me alone . You 're drunk .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: You know I 'm not . Come and give me a kiss !

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: You stink of alcohol . Let me go . BRIGNAClowI want you .He kisses herLUCIEtearing herself awayFaugh !She wipes her mouth furiously

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Enough of that , do you hear ?He seizes her brutallyThat 's enough .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: You hurt me ! Let me go .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Be kind now . How well you look when your temper 's up ! Pretty pet . Must n't be naughty . Come .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: I wo n't .

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Then I 'll make you !They struggle , with low cries , pantingLUCIEat the end of her strengthI can n't ! I can n't ! He puts her on a chair ; then goes to open the door of the bedroom and turns on the electric light . The bed is seen , a vision of white sheets . Brignac comes to his wife . LUCIEmad with terrorThe cave man ! The cave man ! He seizes her . She gives a cry and faints . He carries her towards the bedroom .

div.head: ACT III

stage.stage: The Cour d'Assises . Only two of the four sides of the hall are visible . The footlights nearly correspond with a line drawn diagonally across it . To the left and in front is the seat of the Ministry of State . Further back , to the left , the Court .

Facing the audience , successively , are seated counsel , above them the defendants and , lastly , the gendarmes . In the middle , in front of a table placed for exhibits in the case , the witness stand .
To the right three or four benches for the accommodation of the audience , but only a small part is visible . The jury , which is unseen , is supposed to occupy the place of the prompter 's box .

There are present the Advocate General , the President of the Court and his assessors , counsel for the defence and his learned friends . In the dock are Madame Thomas , Marie Gaubert , Tupin ( Catherine 's husband ) , Lucie , guarded by gendarmes . Among the public Madame d'Amergueux , Brignac , the clerk .
At the rise of the curtain Madame Thomas is standing in the dock .

PRESIDENT [ authoritatively , to counsel for the defence ] Maitre Verdier , this is not the moment for you to address the Court . And I take this occasion to warn you : I tell you plainly I will use all the authority in my power to prevent you from attempting to set up a theory of justification , as I see you are about to do , for the crimes with which the defendants are charged .

sp.speaker: COUNSEL FOR THE DEFENCE
sp.p: You are mistaken , President . I have no intention of the sort . On the contrary , I declare publicly that in my eyes abortion is a crime because it destroys the existence of a creature virtually in being . To allow it would infallibly lead to allowing infanticide . But what I shall try to shew is that by not permitting affiliation , and by not respecting all motherhood , however it is caused , Society has lost the right to condemn a crime rendered excusable by the hypocrisy of its morals and the indifference of the law .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: This is not the moment for your speech . The defendant Thomas : we shall now pass to the second part of your examination .He hunts in his notes , says a word or two in an undertone to the assessor on his right , then to Madame ThomasSo you admit the abominable crimes with which you are charged ?

sp.speaker: MME . THOMAS
sp.p: I must admit them , as you have the proofs .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: And you feel no remorse for the lives of human beings you have destroyed from the sole motive of gain ! The jury will appreciate your attitude .

sp.speaker: COUNSEL
sp.p: Except that you have spared them the trouble !

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Maitre Verdier , I cannot hear you now .To Madame ThomasYou have crippled the work of nature , you have offended against the principle of life , and you never said to yourself that among the beings you stifled before their birth might be one destined to benefit humanity by his greatness . Did you ? Well ?

sp.speaker: MME . THOMAS
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: You did not say so . Very well .

sp.speaker: MME . THOMAS
sp.p: If I had thought about that , I should have perhaps said that there was as much chance — more , perhaps — that he might be a thief or a murderer .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Indeed ! I will not argue with you ; I am not going to give you the chance to expound your criminal ideas here .

sp.speaker: MME . THOMAS
sp.p: My counsel will do it better than me .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: We 'll see about that . COUNSELwith a smileIt might , perhaps , be well for you , President , not to contemn in advance the rights of the defence . PRESIDENTirritatedMaitre Verdier , you have no right to address me ! And you will be good enough to moderate your expressions . I regret to say that from the opening of this case you have adopted an attitude that you can , perhaps , carry off at Paris , but that I shall certainly not countenance here . Pray take notice of that .

sp.speaker: COUNSEL
sp.p: At the Paris bar —

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: I cannot hear you now .

sp.speaker: COUNSEL
sp.p: At the Paris —

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: I cannot hear you now ! Kindly be seated .

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: D'AMERGUEUXamong the public , to her neighbor , M. de ForgeauWhat an excellent judge M. Calvon is . He is to dine with us tomorrow : I shall congratulate him .

sp.speaker: M. DE FORGEAU
sp.p: A judge of the old stamp .

sp.speaker: MME . D'AMERGUEUX
sp.p: He recognizes us . Did you see him give a little nod ?She directs her smiles at the President

sp.speaker: M. DE FORGEAU
sp.p: Yes . Hush .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Marie Gaubert , stand up .A thin little woman rises to her feetYour name is Marie Gaubert . How old are you ?

sp.speaker: SCHOOLMISTRESS
sp.p: Twenty-seven .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Profession ?

sp.speaker: SCHOOLMISTRESS
sp.p: Schoolmistress .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Do you admit the facts with which you are charged ?

sp.speaker: SCHOOLMISTRESS
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: What have you to say in your defence ?

sp.speaker: SCHOOLMISTRESS
sp.p: I did n't think I was doing wrong .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Your levity astounds me . You are a schoolmistress , and you do not understand that the sacred mission entrusted to you of preparing men and women for the glory and responsibility of the future entails on you the duty of giving an example yourself ! It is your business to conduct the course of elementary instruction in civic morality , and this is how you practise it ! Have you nothing to answer ? According to my notes you undertook the nursing of your two children yourself . Do you love them ?

sp.speaker: SCHOOLMISTRESS
sp.p: It was just because I loved them .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: But you decided that two were enough . You made up your mind to limit the work of the Almighty .

sp.speaker: SCHOOLMISTRESS
sp.p: I should have asked nothing better than to have four or five children .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Indeed ! Then let me tell you that you did not take the best means to arrive at that result .He laughs and looks at his assessor on the right , then at Madame d'Amergueux . She signals her congratulations to him

sp.speaker: SCHOOLMISTRESS
sp.p: You have to be able to feed your children .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Ah , there ! No ! At a pinch I could understand that excuse — a very bad one — being employed in the case of other women ; but not in yours , who enjoy the incomparable advantage of being protected by the State . You are never out of work .

sp.speaker: SCHOOLMISTRESS
sp.p: I earn eighty-three francs a month . My husband , who is a teacher , too , gets as much . That makes a hundred and sixty-six francs a month to live on and bring up two children . When there were four of us , we could almost do it ; with five it would have been impossible .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: You omit to say that during your confinement you have the right to a month 's leave with full salary .

sp.speaker: SCHOOLMISTRESS
sp.p: That used to be true , President . It is so no longer . A departmental circular of 1900 informed us that the funds were insufficient for more than half salaries to be paid , as a rule , at such times . To obtain the whole salary , a detailed report from the inspector is required , and you must petition for it .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Then why not petition ?

sp.speaker: SCHOOLMISTRESS
sp.p: It 's hard to seem like a beggar simply because you have feelings .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Proud , are you ?

sp.speaker: SCHOOLMISTRESS
sp.p: There 's no law against that .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: So that is why you went to the defendant Thomas ?

sp.speaker: SCHOOLMISTRESS
sp.p: Yes , sir . My husband and I arranged our little finances so : the evening our salaries were paid we used to divide the money into different parts and put them by ; so much for rent , so much for food , so much for clothing . We just managed to get along by calculating carefully , and more than once having to cut down expenses that seemed inevitable . The prospect of a third child upset everything . It made our existence impossible . We should have all gone hungry . And then the inspectors and the head mistresses do n't like you to have many children , especially if you nurse them yourself . The last time I was nursing I was made to hide myself — I only had ten minutes during the break at ten o'clock and again at two ; and when my mother brought the baby , I had to take him into a dark closet .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: That has nothing to do with it .

sp.speaker: COUNSEL
sp.p: Yes , President , it has . It ought to be known how the State , which preaches the increase of the population , treats its servants when they have children . PRESIDENTfuriouslyI can n't hear you now !To the schoolmistressYou have n't anything more to say ?

sp.speaker: SCHOOLMISTRESS
sp.p: No , sir .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Sit down .

sp.speaker: MME . D'AMERGUEUX
sp.p: I think M. Calvon lets their counsel talk too much .

sp.speaker: M. DE FORGEAU
sp.p: He 's rather afraid of him .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Tupin , stand up . TUPINa man of mean and wretched appearanceAfter you , Calvon .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: What 's that ?

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: I said , ‘ After you , Calvon . ’ That 's your name , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: I warn you I shall not stand the least insolence from you .

lg.l: I said , ‘ After you , Calvon , ’ just as you said , ‘ Stand up Tupin . ’
If that 's insolence , I did n't begin it .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: I will have you removed . Stand up .

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: All right . It 'll let me stretch my legs a bit .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Your profession ?

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: Electrician .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: You were once . It 's a long time since you worked regularly .

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: There 's no work to be had .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Because you look for it at the wineshop . The police give the worst account of you .

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: I am not surprised they do n't like me : I never liked them .Laughter

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Silence there : or I shall have the court cleared .To TupinThe name of your wife has been found among the papers of the defendant Thomas . Catherine Tupin , maiden name Bidois . Where is Catherine Tupin ? Stand up . Very well , sit down again .To TupinYou tried to conceal your wife from the police .

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: I did n't think they were good company for her . PRESIDENTpretending not to hearYou then gave yourself up on your own confession that it was you who took her to this abominable woman 's house .

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: You speak like a book .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: You persisted in the confession of your guilt . Did you want to go to prison ?

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: Why , that 's an idea ! You get fed and sheltered there anyway .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: The prison conditions are certainly better than those you are accustomed to .

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: Now you 're talking .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: When you were arrested you were completely destitute . The remains of your furniture had been sold , and you were on the eve of finding yourself without a roof over your head . Doubtless you will blame Society , too . Your insubordinate character leads you to frequent Socialist clubs ; and when you do not affect , as you do now , a cynical carelessness in your speech , you are used to repeat the empty phrases you have learnt from the propagandist pamphlets that poison the minds of the working classes . But we know you . If you are a victim , it is to your own vices . You are a hardened drinker .

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: Lately , that 's true .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: You admit it . Extraordinary !

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: What 's that prove ?

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Your eldest daughter is known to the police of Paris as a prostitute . One of your sons has been sentenced to a year 's imprisonment for theft . Is that true ?

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: Possibly .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: A little less proud now ? That 's right . Well , now , you took your wife to this woman . Why ?

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: Because I thought it was enough to have brought seven wretched creatures into the world .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: If you had continued to be the honest and industrious workman you were once , you might have had another child without its necessarily growing up wretched .

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: No , sir . Not with five . It 's impossible .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: I do n't understand .

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: I say that a working man 's family , however much they work and economize , can n't support itself when there are five children .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: If that is true , there are — and it is to the credit of the Society that you despise — there are , I say , numerous charitable organizations which are , so to speak , on the watch for the victims of misfortune and make it a point of honor to leave none without succor . TUPINexcitedlyOh , and that seems all right to you , that a working man , who has n't any vice and does his duty , which is to work and — we 're told , too — have plenty of children , it seems all right to you that that should simply lead to beggary .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Yes , yes ; I recognize the wineshop orator . So you say that a household can n't exist with five children . Thank God , there is more than one in that condition which goes neither to ask for charity nor to an abortionist .

sp.speaker: MME . TUPIN
sp.p: You 're wrong .

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: Shall I prove that you 're wrong ?

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: That does n't seem to me to have much to do with the case .

sp.speaker: MME . TUPIN
sp.p: Yes , it has .

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: Pardon me . If I prove it , people will understand how I came to do what I did .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Very well . But be short .

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: I 've given my counsel my accounts for a month . Let him read it to you .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Very well .The counsel rises

sp.speaker: COUNSEL
sp.p: Here it is .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: You are not Tupin 's counsel .

sp.speaker: COUNSEL
sp.p: No , President , but my learned friends have done me the honor — for which I thank them — to confide to me the task of dealing in my speech with the case as a whole , reserving to themselves to deal with particular aspects of it as they relate to their clients .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: I will hear you now solely for the purpose of reading these accounts . But this is not the time for you to address the court . You understand : I will hear the accounts and nothing more ?

sp.speaker: COUNSEL
sp.p: Certainly , President .He readsThe daily nourishment of five children consists of a four-pound loaf , soup of vegetables and dripping , and a stew which costs ninety centimes . Total , 3f . 75c . This is the expenditure of the father : Return ticket for tram , 30c . Tobacco , 15c . Dinner , 1f . 25c . The rent is 300f . Clothing for the whole family , and boots : sixteen pairs of boots for the children at 4f . 50c . each , four for the parents at 8f . : total again , 300f . Total for the year : 2 , 600f . The expenditure then must be set down at 2 , 600f . Tupin , who is an exceptional workman , earned 160f . a month , that is to say , 2 , 100f . a year . There is therefore an annual deficit of 500f . As I have promised , I will not add a word .He sits down

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: D'AMERGUEUXto her husbandHe might well have saved the three sous a day for tobacco .

sp.speaker: COUNSEL
sp.p: Does the Court wish to have this paper put in ?

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: There is no object in that .To TupinI will not quarrel with your figures : I accept them . But I repeat : there are charitable institutions .

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: And I repeat that I do n't want to beg .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: You prefer to commit what is almost infanticide ? A man whose daughter is on the streets and whose son is a thief can accept charity without degradation . TUPINexcitedThey were n't then . If they 've fallen to that , it 's because with so many other children besides , I could n't look after my son as rich people look after theirs , and because my daughter was seduced and abandoned — because she was hungry ! No , but you must have a heart of stone to bring that up against me !

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: And it 's not your fault either that you 've become a drunkard ?

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: I 'll tell you . You know the proverb : ‘ When there 's no hay in the manger —. ’ Well , when the pinch came at home , I and my wife began to quarrel over each new baby . Each of us accused the other of having made things worse for the first ones . Well , I 'll cut it short . If I went to the wineshop , why , it 's warm there , and you do n't hear the brats crying and their mother complaining . And the drink helps you to forget , so it does , to forget !

sp.speaker: MME . TUPIN
sp.p: It 's good to forget , so it is !

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: It 's my fault if you like , but that 's how we got poorer and poorer .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: And when you had your last child , did n't that serve as a lesson to you ?

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: The last one did n't cost anything . PRESIDENTabsentlyAh !

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: He came into the world deformed and sickly . He was conceived in misery , in want — his mother was worn out .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: And his father a drunkard !

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: If you like . Well , he came badly into the world — he could never have been anything but a cripple . But he did n't want for anything ! They took him in at the hospital and begged me to let him stay there .

sp.speaker: MME . TUPIN
sp.p: He was a curiosity for the doctors .

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: They looked after him , I tell you . They did n't leave him for a minute . He was made to live in spite of himself , so to speak . The other children , who were strong , they let them perish of want . With half the care and the money that was spent on the sickly one they might have made fine fellows of all the rest .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Then that is why you made away with the next ?

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: For all the good he 'd have had in the world , if he could , he 'd say , thank you .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: You ought not to have had him .

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: That 's true . But we poor folk , we do n't know the dodges rich people have so as only to have the children they want , and take their fun all the same : worse luck !

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: If everyone was of your opinion our country would be in a bad way . But your country , doubtless , is nothing to you ?

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: I 've heard say : ‘ A man 's country is where he is well off . ’ I 'm badly off everywhere .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: And you are equally lost to any interest in humanity .

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: If humanity can n't get on without a set of wretches like me , let it go smash !

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Well , the jury can estimate your sense of morality . You may sit down . Night has come . The ushers bring lamps .

sp.speaker: MME . D'AMERGUEUX
sp.p: I should n't like to meet that man of an evening in a lonely place .

sp.speaker: M. DE FORGEAU
sp.p: Nor I . Now for Madame Brignac — that was . My dear lady , what a dreadful thing !

sp.speaker: MME . D'AMERGUEUX
sp.p: Dreadful !

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: We have now only to examine the facts concerning Lucie and Annette Jarras .To the defendant ThomasStand up . This girl , Annette Jarras , was your victim . What have you to say ?

sp.speaker: MME . THOMAS
sp.p: Nothing .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: You do n't trouble yourself about it ? Well , we know your heart is not easy to move .

sp.speaker: MME . THOMAS
sp.p: If I told you that I was led to do what I did by pity , you would n't believe me .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Probably not . But you can try to make us believe . The defendant has the right to say whatever he thinks fit — always under the control of the court , of course .

sp.speaker: MME . THOMAS
sp.p: It 's not worth while .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Yes , yes ; go on . The jury is listening to you .

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: THOMASon a sign from her counselA girl came to me one day . She was a servant . Her master had had her . I refused to do what she asked me : she went away and threw herself into the water . Another , whom I would n't help , was tried here for infanticide . So , since then , when others have come to me , I have agreed ; I have prevented more than one suicide and more than one crime .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: So it was from pity , out of charity that you acted . The prosecution will reply that you never forgot to exact heavy payment .

sp.speaker: MME . THOMAS
sp.p: And you , are n't you paid for condemning others ?

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Those whom you condemned to death and executed yourself , were innocent .

sp.speaker: MME . THOMAS
sp.p: You prosecute me ; but the surgeons who guarantee sterility get decorated !

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: You forget this young girl who died as the result of your action , Annette Jarras . She was eighteen , in the full enjoyment of health ; now she is in the grave .Lucie breaks into sobsLook at her sister by your side ; listen to her crying . Ask her now if she does not curse you .

sp.speaker: MME . THOMAS
sp.p: She would bless me if I had succeeded . PRESIDENTto LucieDefendant Lucie Jarras , stand up .

sp.speaker: M
sp.p: DE FORGEAUto his neighborBrignac must think himself lucky to have got his divorce .

sp.speaker: MME . D'AMERGUEUX
sp.p: Speak lower ; he 's behind us . I am against divorce , but in this case —

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: You have heard the defendant Thomas . What have you to say ? LUCIEthrough her sobsNothing . Nothing .She sinks back upon her bench

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Do you admit —?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Yes , yes ; I admit everything . I 've told you so already .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: You did not want your child to come into the world ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: I did n't want it to .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Out of pity for him . I knew what sort of a life he would have , and I risked my own to save him from it . I acted like a good mother .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: What you say is simply monstrous .SilenceYou , now , have not the excuse of poverty . Your child would not have suffered from want .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: He would have suffered from disease , and that is as bad as want .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: No theories , please . Only facts .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Yes ; facts , nothing but facts . You can see the theory of it for yourself . I had two children , two little girls . One is a deaf mute , the other had convulsions . She is dead now . The doctors told me that that was due to the alcoholized condition of my husband , whose father had been in the same state .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Most unfortunate .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Be pleased to let me speak !

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Very good . I will answer you .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: One of the doctors is famous — Dr. Hourtin .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: A specialist who sees alcoholism everywhere ! LUCIEmore vigorouslyThose doctors told me that if my husband did not change his mode of life , any further children I had by him would , perhaps , be worse than the first , nervous degenerates . The very evening that Professor Hourtin came to see me , my husband came back from some festivity in a state of excitement —She stops

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Well ? Is that all ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: No ; I 'll have the courage to say everything . I have nothing to lose now .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Please take note that it is not I who make you go on .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: No ; you would probably prefer if I did n't .Controlling her voiceDuring the day something had happened — something serious — that revealed to me all the hideousness of his moral character . I determined no longer to be his wife . He came in , gay with drinking . In spite of my prayers and resistance , my cries of hatred and disgust , he chose that evening to exercise his rights — his rights ! He took me by force ; he outraged me .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: He was your husband ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Then —

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Of course . The next morning I left his house . PRESIDENTstartingM. Brignac is not in question .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: I bring him in question !

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: I shall not allow you to bring charges against persons unconnected with the case .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: He ought to be in my place .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: His name does not figure in the indictment .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Because your justice does n't want to put responsibility on the right shoulders !

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: I forbid you to speak like that of M. Brignac .

sp.speaker: COUNSEL
sp.p: Pardon me , President .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: I cannot hear you now .

sp.speaker: COUNSEL
sp.p: That is why I ask to be heard .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: What do you want ?

sp.speaker: COUNSEL . M
sp.p: Brignac is called as a witness .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: We have already heard him .

sp.speaker: COUNSEL
sp.p: Allow me to remind you of the terms of Article 319 of the Criminal Code , which authorizes me to say against him as well as against his evidence whatever may help the defence .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: And let me remind you of Article 311 in the same Code , which enjoins you to express yourself with moderation .

sp.speaker: COUNSEL
sp.p: I ask you , President , kindly to recall M. Brignac to the bar . I have a question to put to him through you . PRESIDENTafter consulting with his assessorsUsher , ask M. Brignac kindly to come here . BRIGNACcoming forward to the barHere , President .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: What is your question , Maitre Verdier ?

sp.speaker: COUNSEL . M
sp.p: Brignac has heard all that has just been said ?

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: COUNSEL
sp.p: Then I beg M. Brignac to review all the factors in his memory . I make a supreme appeal to his conscience , and I beg you , President , to put this question to M. Brignac : does M. Brignac not recognize himself as morally responsible for the crime imputed to Madame Lucie Jarras , his divorced wife ?

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: I shall not put the question . Is that all ?

sp.speaker: COUNSEL
sp.p: For the moment , yes . PRESIDENTto BrignacYou may return to your place , Deputy . But since the defence , with an assumption of excessive liberty , appears desirous of incriminating you , the Court may , perhaps , be permitted to express to you here the high esteem in which it personally holds you .He half rises from his chair , bowing to Brignac

sp.speaker: BRIGNAC
sp.p: I thank you , President .He goes back to his place

lg.l: Then it 's true what they say , that
Brignac is to be Minister of Justice in the next Government ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: No , President . PRESIDENTwith a gesture of wearinessGo on , then ; I 'm listening .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: When I felt a child coming to life within me of a man who was nothing more to me , whose name even I no longer bore , and whom I hated with my whole soul , I prevented it from being born to a destiny of misery . I consider that I had the right to refuse the task of motherhood when it was forced on me against my will .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: I shall not allow you to justify an act which is a crime by law .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: I have nothing on my conscience to reproach myself with .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Then you have a singularly indulgent conscience . All this comes from your pride . If you had not entered into a struggle with your husband , you would still bear a respected name and you would not be there .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: I knew that any child of his would be a degenerate . Had I not the right to refuse ?

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: I loved him no longer . Had I not the right to refuse ?

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Well , then , have the courage to say that woman in the marriage of today is a slave whom man can reduce to be the instrument of his pleasure ! Just as he likes he can leave her sterile or give her children — imperil her happiness , her life , or her health , and pledge her whole future without having to render more account to her than a bull who is put to a cow ! If that 's it , very well ! But say so ! At least , let innocent girls know the shameful bargain that men offer them , with love for a bait and the law for a trap ! PRESIDENTcoldlyYou were the cause of your young sister 's death . You took her with you . LUCIEcalmerYes .She stops

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Our money was soon spent . Annette got some music lessons to give , but they sent her away when they found out her condition . I did sewing .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Then you earned some money .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: I could not get work every day . When I did , I earned fifteen sous for twelve hours . It 's true I was not clever ; there are women who earn one franc twenty-five - . We were seized by despair at the thought of the child that was coming .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: That was not a reason to take your sister and her child to their deaths .Lucie is seized by a nervous shudder and does not answerAnswer me .

sp.speaker: COUNSEL
sp.p: Let her take a minute , President . LUCIEpulling herself togetherI wanted to get her into a hospital , but they only take you in at the end of pregnancy . At Paris there are institutions , it seems , but not in the provinces .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: You might have asked for relief .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: We had not been the requisite six months in the town . And afterwards , what could we have done with the child ?

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: If she was unable to bring it up , your sister could have taken it to the ‘ Enfants Assistes . ’

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Yes , abandoned it . We did think of that . We made inquiries .

sp.speaker: COUNSEL
sp.p: A certificate is required that the applicant to the society is without means . An inquiry is made and the application may be accepted or refused . In the meantime the child may die .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: They only take in children on condition that the mother shall not know where the child is , that she shall never see it or have news of it . Once a month only she is told if it is alive or dead ; nothing more .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Go on , madam . But facts , if you please .

sp.speaker: LUCIE
sp.p: Yes . I begged my husband to take Annette and me back . He would not .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Kindly come to the defendant Thomas . LUCIEwith constantly rising emotionAnnette reproached herself for having accepted what she called my sacrifice . She said that she was the cause of all my trouble .PauseOne day I was fetched ; I found her dead at this woman 's .A fit of sobbing seizes her : her nerves break down completely . She criesMy little sister ! my poor little sister ! PRESIDENTCompassionately , to the usherTake her away . Call the doctor .Lucie , still crying out , is led away . Her emotion has communicated itself to everyone in court . The President continues to the defendantsHas no one else among you anything further to say in his defence ? TUPINexcitedOh , if we said everything we should be here till tomorrow !

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: TUPINequally excitedYes , till tomorrow , so we should !

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: And then we should n't be done , I can tell you !

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Then I will hear the Advocate-General .

sp.speaker: SCHOOLMISTRESS
sp.p: But you 're not going to condemn us ? It is n't possible . I have n't said everything —

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: It 's not we who are guilty !

sp.speaker: SCHOOLMISTRESS
sp.p: I was afraid of getting a bad name . We had n't the means , either , to bring up another .

sp.speaker: MME
sp.p: TUPINgreatly worked upSo that 's it ! So that 's all the children that we bring up get by it ! What 's the use of talking ? The men have n't thought of changing it — well then , we must do it ! We women ! We must strike ! We — the mothers ! The great strike — the strike of the mothers ! Cries among the public , ‘ Yes , yes . ’

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Silence !

sp.speaker: MME . TUPIN
sp.p: What 's the good of using ourselves up to make more wretched men and gay women ! For others to use !

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: It 's not we that are guilty !

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Sit down ! TUPINdrowning his voiceIt 's the men who 've not given us enough to feed our children that are guilty !

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Sit down !

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: The men who tell us to have other children , while those we have are rotting with hunger !

sp.speaker: COUNSEL
sp.p: The criminal is the man who seduced little Annette !

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Silence !

sp.speaker: MME . THOMAS
sp.p: Yes , where 's he ? Where 's he ? You have n't taken him up ! Because he 's a man and your laws —

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Guards !

sp.speaker: MME . THOMAS
sp.p: And your laws are made by men !

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Guards !

sp.speaker: MME . THOMAS
sp.p: And all the men who got with child the girls I delivered , did you prosecute them ? During the following , an anger which becomes a fury seizes the accused . They are all on their feet , except the schoolmistress , who continues to sob and utter words that no one hears . The President is also on his feet ; he tries vainly to restore silence by knocking on his desk with a paper-knife , but he cannot make himself heard . The tumult increases till the fall of the curtain , the voices of the counsel for the defence and his clients drowning those of the President and the Procuror .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: I will have you removed to prison !

sp.speaker: MME. THOMAS
sp.p: The fine gentlemen who take mistresses ! And the young ones who humbug little work girls !

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: I 'll have you removed to prison .

sp.speaker: PROCUROR
sp.p: Guards , can n't you keep that crowd of fanatics quiet ?

sp.speaker: COUNSEL
sp.p: You have no right to insult the defendants !

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: That 's all they 've done from the beginning !

sp.speaker: PROCUROR
sp.p: Make that howling mob be quiet ! The defendants have no respect for the Court !

sp.speaker: COUNSEL
sp.p: And you , Advocate General , have no respect for justice !

sp.speaker: PROCUROR
sp.p: If their crime inspires you with sympathy , it only fills me with indignation .

sp.speaker: COUNSEL
sp.p: They are right . They are not guilty ! The respect that you lack —

sp.speaker: PROCUROR
sp.p: I demand —

sp.speaker: COUNSEL
sp.p: The guilt is at the door of the morals that brand the unmarried mother .

sp.speaker: THE PUBLIC
sp.p: Bravo !

sp.speaker: PROCUROR
sp.p: I ask that counsel for the defence —

sp.speaker: COUNSEL
sp.p: Every woman with child ought to be respected in whatever circumstances her child has come into being . Applause .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Maitre Verdier , by virtue of Article 43 of the Rules —

sp.speaker: COUNSEL
sp.p: Their crime is not an individual , but a social , crime .

sp.speaker: PROCUROR
sp.p: It is a crime against nature !

sp.speaker: COUNSEL
sp.p: It is not a crime ; it is a revolt against nature !

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Guards , remove the defendants !The guards do not hear or do not understandMaitre Verdier , if I have to employ force — Tumult in court . COUNSELsucceeding by the force of his voice in imposing a short silenceIt is a revolt against nature ! A revolt that fills my heart with pity , at the cause of which all the force of my mind is roused to indignation ! Yes ; I look forward with eagerness to that hour of freedom when the store-house of science shall give to everyone the means , without a restraint that is only hypocrisy , without the profanation of love , to have none but the children he wants ! That will be indeed a victory over nature , that cruel nature which sows with criminal profusion the life that she watches die with indifference . But meanwhile — The tumult begins again .

sp.speaker: PRESIDENT
sp.p: Guards , clear the court ! Guards ! Guards , remove the defendants . The sitting is adjourned . The judges put on their caps and rise .

sp.speaker: MME . THOMAS
sp.p: It 's not me who kills the innocents ! I 'm no murderess !

sp.speaker: SCHOOLMISTRESS
sp.p: Mercy ! Mercy !

sp.speaker: MME . TUPIN
sp.p: She 's no murderess !

sp.speaker: TUPIN
sp.p: She 's right . She 's no murderess !

sp.speaker: MME . THOMAS
sp.p: It 's the men that are guilty ! The men ! All the men ! The judges leave by the narrow door leading to their room . During the last words their red robes are seen gradually disappearing .
